hi everyone Boris Johnson why here the Internet's busiest music and it's time for a review of the the new Harry Styles album fine line this is a new full-length album from singer/songwriter One Direction member mr. Harry Styles following up his 2017 debut and I will say despite not being crazy about that record so far as One Direction members going solo are concerned harry has shown the most potential as Zayn and Liam as well as Niall have all put out their own solo works I haven't got the same sense that they have artistic abilities and tastes that extend as far as Harry's don't you forget about my boy Lewis though he's gonna put out the best album next year ten out of ten 20 out of 20 Louis Louis Louis Louis well while Harry has put out the best solo work so far I still think there is a lot of room to grow artistically as well as just just defining Harry's musical style and voice but honestly with fine line I feel like we are not really any closer to that as yet again Harry serves up another batch of inconsistent tracks even nondescript songs that hop around from blue-eyed soul to sad boy Foulke some 70s rock some contemporary pop - there is a bit of a vintage Flair that runs throughout much of the record but I wouldn't say Harry even leans on that heavily enough for it to be a central idea or concept of the album essentially we've gone from one direction to pretty much no direction the indecisiveness of this record begins right away with the opening track which features some subtly swaggered vocals some driving drums and bass it sounds like something off of a Strokes record but then it slightly enhanced with these bright shots of vocal harmonies these DDD's it sounds like something out of a grizzly bear song or a slick piece of pop or soft rock out of the 70s maybe even little Eagles ish the song at the core of doll is absolutely boring although it's hard to tell because Harry does so little to sell the damn thing vocally the mix totally sucks too the drums sound like they're behind a wall the group vocals overpower everything else harry has such little vocal presence on the track the acoustic guitar that's in there very quietly is so faint it might as well just not even be there I was pretty bored by watermelon sugar as a single and I can't say I'm much more into it now that I'm hearing it on the album it feels like another groovy pop throwback but yet again Harry doesn't really sell the track vocally and this is the type of instrumental a top-notch soul singer or even Freddie Mercury would have murdered back in the day but Harry's performance here is just middle-of-the-road not interesting at all I can't say the lyrics are all that profound either as Harry is mostly singing about comparing love or intimacy to the euphoria of the sweetness of fruit whoa comparing like love and sex to two fruit that's never happened before the song adore you next is a step toward the nondescript I can't say I get the appeal of the song as a single does it not just sound like a Marine v song I mean sure maybe maroon 5 would not be the first band to employ the synth bass that this track has but the drums the groove the singing the overly slick production it all just sounds something like Adam Levine and the gang would do but with a few more 80s nods it's very so what I like the song lights up as a single with its very moody take on blue-eyed soul with its bright shots of group vocals but the more I listen to it the more I feel like the structure of this track is kind of malformed the verses don't pop as much as they could the choruses don't pop as much as they could all because the progression of the track just feels a bit muddy also if you strip the song back of all these showy vintage bits of instrumentation I can't help but feel like the song itself would be incredibly boring but not nearly as boring as the song cherry which actually is pretty stripped back and acoustic and it may just be candidate for worst song on the record for one it is way too early in the tracklist to start putting out songs like this this quiet finger picked acoustic ballad with vocals that are so subdued they sound nearly comatose not to mention that for whatever reason the vocals on this track sound way more anonymous than any other vocal on the rest of the record I could not pick this out as Harry Styles do save my life on top of it the whole thing sounds like Peter Gabriel's Solsbury Hill but on xanax and completely stripped of any likeable qualities thankfully there are some highlights that come around the halfway point though like the song falling it's a somber piano tune where the vocals are actually legitimately impressive especially when Harry hits that one very loud and very high note in the second half of the track the singing is great and shines despite how basic and plain the piano instrumental is certainly a powerful and emotional moment on the record even if the lyrics aren't the deepest in the world to be so lonely though isn't nearly as gratifying mostly because I feel like the song doesn't really live up to the title or the sentiment of the track with it's flirty acoustics an island inspired groove the whole thing sounds like sociably dancing the night away with a bunch of drunk boomers on a beach resort if this thing is lonely its Jimmy Buffett or Vampire Weekend lonely it's not Conor Oberst or Elliott Smith lonely the song she though is a transition into a fusion of very dramatic 70s rock and soul with these extended kind of demented buzzing screaming guitar solo passages at the finish that sound like something Jack White would just freak out over but the whole thing sounds like a kind of gentrified version of a sad sad soul anthem out of the 60s or the 70s think something like James Brown it's a man's man's man's world still the track gets hard a lot harder than most of the songs here even if most of the appeal I think comes down to the instrumental also the bright vocal shots of Shay the unexpected stylistic twists and turns continue on to the track sunflower vol 6 which sounds like what you would get if you forced of Montreal and Vampire Weekend to write a bit of a reggae inspired hit that was meant to rule the radio waves in the 2000s because of the unlikely mix of sounds and hooky melody is it's certainly one of the better tracks here the record does not pick up from here though unfortunately the vintage folk pop ripoff Canyon moon just sounds like a bad bit of Paul Simon runoff also the grading and silly group vocals on treat people with kindness which come off as very unselfish yeah they're tough to stomach the closing track on this thing the title track sounds like a bad read on some falsetto vocals and acoustic chords from a boney vert record and then a big Sufjan Stevens sized instrumental finish most likely there are two dudes right now in a college dorm somewhere having this conversation it would be so epic if boney vert and Suzanne collabs well this is certainly what it would sound like if it were bad with Harry's very weak falsettos way too much reverb a boring set of chords this song goes absolutely nowhere fast and then the big instrumental finish basically feels like not just putting lipstick on a pig but also a pair of Chanel pumps and $1,000 dress overall I'm not very crazy about this record it does have some highlights but for every highlight there is also a pretty crummy track too majority of the other songs are just merely tolerable I'm pretty indifferent to the whole thing although I can't say I will go into another Harry Styles album after this with nearly as much hope I'm feeling a light to decent five on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it uh hi everyone here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new glass Beach record the first glass beach album this thing is out now via run for cover records and admittedly I am kind of late to the party whoa party I put the record off again and again and again as I was covering other stuff throughout the year and maybe I shouldn't have but I was being constantly reminded by fans that this album was something special and even though I didn't review the record up until now I had listened to it here and there throughout the year and I was pretty impressed initially with the diverse array of influences going into the tracklist this LP not only serves up a pretty rowdy mix of power pop and emo but the songs here also incorporate elements of jazz indie tronic music neo psyche the chord progression and peppy pacing of the track bedroom community sounds like something out of a cutesy anime theme song with a constantly shape-shifting tracklist the first glass beach album is a lot to take in at 15 tracks in one hour not only is there a lot of stylistic diversity across the record but also some of the songs on here kind of intricate complex or a bit long-winded working in multiple phases the band really has a drive to produce these rock songs that are energetic but also sound like these miniature punky orchestras and even though the execution on this thing is wild it's a little loose the end result is still pretty grand and exhilarating like the track neon glow which is a very noisy piece of power pop elevated by these tight twinkly melodies that pop in every few bars or so it's aggressive but also intricate and kind of fun also the transition after the halfway point of the song where we start getting some jangly sad horn backed instrumentation and the amazing finale the build-up that it tops things off with that's a pretty incredible moment - there's also the intro track classic Jade eyes which has a very quiet spotlit vocal and piano intro that's kind of theatrical it sounds like a sad sad show tune or like something that would kick off an epic rock operas such as MC ARS Black Parade but then the gentle synth leads and groovy bass that the song transitions into pretty quickly after the intro that sounds like something that is a little J pop inspired actually and with the dreary horn passages that come after along with the punky finale the track just gets better and better meanwhile the song Glass Beach kicks off like a fiery emo rager it sounds straight out of the 2000s vocally it's just letting it all out emotionally speaking I loved the filthiest hell drums on this track the kind of angular geometric synth lines the melody work on the track it's more and more skilled as the track progresses along these extended chord progressions it's beautiful it's anthemic it's electrifying these tracks are just a few examples of the multi-genre impressive progressive dynamic highlights on most of this record and given the level of attention to detail on individual songs here of course there is a lot of attention to how all of these songs are flowing together on the entire album - for the most part the tracklist on this thing is sequenced really really well across the album there are nice transitions from multi-phased epics to beaming anthems to ambient palate cleansers I'd also like to quickly mention the lyrics on this LP - which mind you aren't bad but I think that depends on your point of view just reading the lyrics aloud out of context one might classify them as just being boring annoying emote right I get how some people might have a cynical reaction when reading lyrics like but when we're with all our friends can we just pretend that no one can hurt us because hey I love you okay it's so hard to say that I fucking need you to but I think the record overall is pretty self-aware in how over-the-top it is emotionally and compositionally especially since on the compositional end the band goes to such lengths to in a way overdo it in that sense I think the vocals fit the album very well because everything on the record feels so dramatic and theatrical as if every song or musical phase of the record is a different scene of some sort my biggest issue with this LP aside from a few of the interludes feeling a little too off the beat path a little too unrelated to everything else going on not really landing as a result of that my big biggest issue here is that the record in my opinion does not really stick the landing as things start to turn downward in my opinion around areum there's something I should say about the record generally before I get too deep into this track and that's the vocals in my opinion are the Achilles heel of the record maybe one of my least favorite things about the record yeah they're kind of grating they are unapologetically whiny but ultimately they're not as skilled as everything else going into the project and to me that feels a bit off-putting however in the context of what the band is doing instrumentally what they are trying to message to their audience as well the mix of genres going into this thing 90% of the time or more the vocals work not on this track though because glass beach decides to feed the singing through some kind of obnoxious vocoder I really don't know but it makes the singing truly intolerable to me especially once it starts getting more aggressive I just can't stand it it's excruciating I scramble to skip this track every time the track soft is okay I guess but the interstitial tracks here really don't land when they are shouldered between songs that are more core to the record but simultaneously not all that great which brings me to Yoshi's Island which is maybe the least gratifying of the longer songs here at this point it just feels like the band is dragging the record out unnecessarily I mean stylistically it doesn't really bring all that much to the table outside of a vaguely tropical vibe coming out of the chords overall I think the tracklist would have felt a lot less flabby without this one orchids though is a pretty decent closer the Soaring sad and heavy vocals and instrumentation presented here feel a lot like Andrew Jackson jihads knife man the closing track to that record the big epic finale not quite as big here by comparison but still pretty hard-hitting and in certainly a passionate moment on the record that ties things up pretty nicely so overall there are some interludes here that are just okay the ending drags on a little bit there are a few glaringly bad ideas but for the most part the first glass beach album is a very good record and impressive debut that has me excited to see where the band is going to go next what they're going to sound like once they start getting even more ambitious and start smoothing out some of the rougher edges that they've presented here as this thing is easily one of the most versatile dynamic and varied incredibly creative records in the fields of emo and power pop that I've heard this decade I'm feeling a strong seven to a light eight on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you could check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana music glass beach forever

uh this new xxx tent ah see own album it's not good bad vibes forever the the new posthumous album from xxx fantasy Onan yes it's not very good and it feels weird saying that because I feel like it not being good has very little to do with the artist the album is named after because bad vibes forever is yet another example in the music industry of an artist's name and legacy being grossly exploited posthumously with an album that is theirs in name and in name only and look not that I'm against the idea of posthumous albums in general I'm very clearly not I mean just earlier this year I loved an album of prints demos but the works on that album as much as maybe if prints were still here he would have disagreed with the idea of putting those demos out the works on that record were still very much undeniably his whereas much of what I'm hearing on this new project over here feels more like weird extras odds and ends left over hooks or random vocal ideas repeated and strung out into a sound like choruses placed against production that they may have had nothing to do with originally and then coupled with features that just seem like they're meant to I don't know caused a stir get people talking get people clicking over onto this album because hey Wayne is on here hey Rick Ross is on here oh my god did you hear there's a blink 182 feature I mean sure there are some collaborations and some features here that certainly make sense the Joey badass feature makes sense given that him and X had worked in the past and the Kemba feature on the same track featuring Joey is actually amazing maybe the best feature on the entire record also having Craig Zen given how edgy some of ex's work used to be in the past is pretty fitting as well but in what way in and what reality does it make sense to have Noah Cyrus on this project and to mention it once again in what way in and what reality does rick ross on this project makes sense like i don't know they're both from florida is that it is that literally all they had in common i mean look there's some tracks on this project that kind of sound like a semi complete ex song but it's so painfully clear that if it weren't for the features that if it weren't for the producers basically filling in all the gaps filling in all the holes that we would have a fraction of the material that we do on this hour-long album their tracks on this thing we're literally the only place where ex's voices is on the hook and it's just a vocal line and it's repeated over and over and then it's the featured artists just rapping the verses on the cut it's barely an ex song it's not even an ex song it just sounds like another person's song but with ex as the feature plus their tracks and vocal takes on this thing that should it should have never seen the light of day like the dancehall tracks on this thing are bad not only that but ex's vocal performances on these tracks seem almost tongue-in-cheek in a way also sometimes the production on this thing isn't even really all that flattering either whether or not it was originally attached to the vocal that ex had laid down to begin with heart-eater i think is a prime example of that the guitar solo on this track is trash i can't tell if the drums and the additional guitars on the cut are just like add-ons or if they were originally meant to line up with the acoustic guitars and vocals that ex had laid down first it just sounds like a total mess and so does the blink-182 appearance on this thing too I'm actually kind of surprised that mark and Travis would be down to do this it's just kind of shocking how ready everyone is to actively take part in just squeezing whatever clout or juice they can possibly get out of exes memory on this project because nobody here can really be convinced like they're making genuinely good music with what X had and left over right I just don't get it how is taking some vocal snippet of a late artist and extending that out over a beat to the point where I guess you get something repetitive something is seeming like a hook some semblance of a chorus and then having some featured artists that that person didn't really have that much of a connection to while they were alive and just having that person wrapped to fill out the rest of the track how is that really a celebration of that artists memory and while yeah tracks like X pitch and some of the more emo folk driven tracks on the record that sound like they could have been on 17 they're not so much my thing but still I would take these moments any day over what feels like an assembly line of producers and features being tacked on to a bunch of odds and ends that are just left over in the X of all not too long ago I gave another very negative opinion of another posthumous X album skins and my issue with that record generally is that it felt very under written very low five very rough around the edges very raw like there wasn't really anything that was all to complete about it and while I didn't really care for that music being released in the way that it did because it just felt really um I don't know just not finished certainly not anything I think should be getting put out there and categorized as an album either way it's actually easier to appreciate that project because at least it feels like an intimate expression of a real idea that X had on bad vibes forever I feel like what we're getting is just leftover X pieces and sounds and those are just being brought to a chop shop and assembled into a new car or something and while that's not true of every single track on this project it happens often enough to the point where it's difficult to enjoy much of any of it this new xx extant aussi own record it's not good you

hi everyone wrist the knee popped you know here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of Griselda's WWC d this is the highly anticipated joint album from the main brains over at Griselda Records Westside gun Benny the butcher Conway three of the hottest artists right now coming out of Buffalo New York essentially putting the city on the hiphop map in the past couple of years a lot of the Griselda hype has been building up to this point this collaborative effort out now and Shady Records and even though it's here it still feels unreal not just because of Griselda's meteoric rise to industry credibility but also the independence and artistic freedom they've been able to maintain while gaining so much popularity it's rare you have artists who are connected to jay-z connected to Eminem and yet they are still putting out records and mixtapes on their own label at their own prolific pace in the grander scheme of Griselda's plan as essential as this project may be it seems more like a bit of a detour as the end goal still seems to be to build Griselda's brand up from the ground up and own it all the way and even though in the past while I have been a little underwhelmed by solo west side projects and solo beni projects I'm hoping that hopping on tracks together will be a surefire formula for keeping things from feeling one-dimensional also exciting to hear these guys work exclusively with derringer and beat butcha for the entirety of this project and rumor has it that they used absolutely no samples on this project no samples all original music so WW CD is 12 tracks and a remix of the conway song bang featuring Eminem at the very end and even though Griselda doesn't exceed my expectations on this project ww CD still shapes up to be everything I hoped an album from these guys coming together would be this thing features a pretty tight 46 minute run no tracklist fillers no weird one-minute bridges to nowhere no poor excuses for beats no structuralist verses that just drag on forever and there's a pretty exciting chemistry between these three guys that undeniable they bring out the best in each other creating something more versatile than the respective Griselda solo efforts over the past year or so but again my major issue with this project is that it does not exceed my expectations all these voices and ideas coming together it's just not greater than the sum of its parts I mean sure Benny and Conway and Westside all reinforce each other pretty well it's like the effect of taking one line of coke and then another line of coke and then a third line of coke they're certainly not a trio sounding heavier on the scale than they are right now but it's not like because they've gotten together on a record all of a sudden they're top-notch storytellers with the most vivid narratives and wordplay this thing is not an only built 4 Cuban Linx it's not even a hell hath no fury lyrically I would say each member of Grizelda is still delivering pretty surface level drug and gun talk sure their dedication to these topics feels a lot realer than when most rappers will just casually mention them and it feels borderline cinematic to when these guys land on a particularly eerie beat like the tuna progression quietly wailing away in the background of chef dreads it makes it sound like something bad is gonna happen or with the track Scotties which features these wobbly detuned chords that sound like something off of a Halloween effects tape or with city on the map featuring these lightly droning bass notes icy elongated piano chords sounds like something out of a creepy detective show soundtrack so with instrumentals like these combined with Conway bars like so if it's smoked Wayne even askin we just pull it up and somebody gonna see a casket it's grittiness you can cut with the knife there are some other strong and potent emotions on this project too that are worth pointing out like with West Side's very focused verse on Freddie hot spot where he goes at length about a murder attempt and feeling very paranoid the heart pumping intensity of having a brush with death hits pretty hard on this one but still moments that are this topical and this narrative are pretty rare on WWC d sometimes the most you can hope for on this one is a great be gruff rapping and a handful of quotables to rise up out of the piles upon piles of coke like on this fantastic set of bars from Benny or on the track chef dreads which is maybe the most lyrical slugfest on the entire project with Conway and Benny and Westside constantly switching off bars between each other there are some equally awesome trade-offs in the first portion of the track Scotty's - and while all these guys do have their moments on this project I will say there is a pretty apparent talent gap within Griselda Benny the butcher is easily the most lyrical technical and methodical rapper of the trio meanwhile Westside makes up for most of his technical and lyrical shortcomings by just having a very standout voice and delivery though it's pretty hard to ignore when he obviously runs out of ideas like toward the tail end of cruiserweight Kok where it feels less like he's rapping and more like he's just making random idle threats that the song really could have done without there are a few tracks in the tracklist here that maybe feel a bit redundant maybe not as potent especially Mosel and my only other major issue with WW CD has to be the features some of which don't even really complement the record like novel at the very end of the seven-minute long old groove his appearance coincides with this really random weird jazzy beats which his delivery is much more bright and soulful than anything else on the record it just sticks out awkwardly also the Eminem feature at the very end is annoying as hell I mean look I give Grizelda credit for putting it at the very finish because most Rahzel the fans are not trying to hear that the best appearance on this thing easily is again actually 50 cent and while I think it's great that 50 sounds more cold-blooded here than he has in years when 50 is your best guest on your project you know you're kind of starting from a low bar look overall I think WW CD is pretty good there are a number of ways which it could have been better but this thing was very much still worth the hype it's also good to not just see the lion's share of this genres attention going to guys like Pusha T and Freddie Gibbs I can also see why guys like Ray Kwan see Griselda in a way as a bit of a spiritual successor to a lot of his work back in the day because in a way it is I'm feeling a strong 6 to a light 7 on this one transition have you in this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should our view next hit the like if you liked please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Grizelda forever

oh hi everyone via theny break tano here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a reviewed the new Hannah diamond record reflections pop singer and songwriter Hannah diamond who has been affiliated with the PC music label for as long as many artists on the label have you could say she was one of their biggest voices as their unique approach to hyper futuristic bubblegum bass was a hot commodity earlier in the decade singles like attachment pink in blue every night we're pretty essential not only in establishing a sonic calling card for the label but also a visual aesthetic but despite Hannah's somewhat alien voice and her retro futuristic fashion giving PC music a pretty bold look right out of the gate her career feels almost like it's been treated as an afterthought in the greater PC roster I mean her debut single dropped in 2013 she played a pretty vital role on both PC music compilations and we're now just getting her debut album in 2019 long after the labels most notable artists like Sophie and Eiji cook have evolved past the sounds that originally put PC music on the map it's also kind of weird there are tracks on this project that are a year two three years old at this point whether or not you've been aware of everything that's happened with Hannah diamond up until this point reflections is still 10 tracks and 39 minutes and honestly it's a lot more underwhelming than I thought it would be not only because AG Cooke an easy funds production on this thing is pretty tame either current standards not exactly pushing the envelope in the way they've been known to over the years but there are just so many songs in the tracklist here that are fleeting forgettable and I'm just not sure how Hannah's heavily touched up and manipulated vocals play out long-term like over more than a few tracks at a time while it has given her a unique aesthetic and a particular flare on singles and in small doses the novelty of sounding like auto-tuned voice to text software with an English accent wears off after a while especially when the hooks are bland and the instrumentation is underwhelming I get it's a style I get it's a sound I get it's a vibe but there's got to be a bolder way of employing it than this because as is the vocals the instrumentation just feel one-dimensional leaving multiple tracks here sounding like a total bore the intro song reflections also the track never again the very slowly paced true is outright tedious and may be my least favorite track here and even the song invisible which narrative Lee sounds like one of the most relatable songs of the bunch it's still difficult to get much out of it emotionally because it's sound also the lyrics feel like I'm listening to something that is the result of programming an AI to produce pop songs that lonely teenagers will relate to but obviously not trying to do that from a place of genuine emotion it's more from a predictive algorithm there are a few tracks in the tracklist here they have strong dance beats maybe an experimental edge that I think is pretty cool the song fade away as well as concrete angel whose final moments get pretty glitchy and abrasive but I still wish the vocals had a stronger presence on both of these tracks at the end of the day the singing just sounds like another piece of synthetic ear candy in the mix that has no more presence or importance than anything else there are a couple of gratifying pop anthems in the tracklist here for sure there is the song shy whose main melodies are so freakin sweet they also contrast very well with the incredibly icy cords hanging in the background the whole thing makes me feel like I'm skating across a starry sky in a tight shiny sequin romper and I'm feeling sexy in the whole time I'm buggin really hard meanwhile the song love goes on also a strong pop appeal on this one and it's one of the few moments where Hannah's vocals have a pretty noticeable human touch they don't feel quite as robotic as they do everywhere else and I think this song is the better for it and fade away make-believe the ending tracks to the album while they are nice they're not anything new for Hannah they're years old at this point they don't really stick out in the tracklist because I think there's just not enough variety sonically across the runtime of the record I feel as if their appeal has kind of waned over the years and Hanish be evolved past this sound at this point in doing something bolder and more interesting at the end of the day while I don't hate this record and I think there are a lot of check boxes filled out here that essentially make this a genuine representation of the unique sounds and ideas that PC is putting out there on the pop landscape today I just wish that Hannah and easy fun and AG just pulled out more stops with this record just went all out on this album and tried to make it one of the bigger and more attention-grabbing statements off the PC roster but that just didn't happen instead they mostly played it safe with the sound they established well over five years ago and failed to expand on it in any major way over the course of 10 tracks feeling a strong 5 to light 6 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantan Oh Hannah diamond reflections forever

Lala hi everyone Green that he snaked an oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new tonight EP two two two this is a brand new EP of music from producer duo Lunas and Hudson Mohawke aka tonight in the earlier half of this decade these guys got together and dropped an EP for the ages a short collection of five tracks that helped bring the burgeoning tide of trap to its knees with zany samples and booming bass and excessive drops okay obviously this EP didn't really bring trap to its knees but there are some songs on it that did catch on pretty wildly I didn't name it my EP of the year even though I do think generally this project is a little underrated and underappreciated I have to specify when I say trap I don't mean any shade of it that would land under the hip-hop umbrella I'm talking about the style of electronic dance music that is inspired by it and that style is still going today but it's not nearly as novel as it was when tonight's debut EP came out and granted while Lunas and HUD MO were far from the first to reinterpret trap music for DJ sets and dance floors the approach they displayed on their debut EP was a lot more colorful and unorthodox than a majority of everything else out there at the time from the incessant vocal samples on higher ground to the pish pish pish percussion bouncing bass and weird bubble sound effects on buggin while there was another single in 2013 HUD Moe and Lunas went back about their business as if this crossover never happened which I guess wasn't hard to do considering this was a collaboration that literally nobody expected ever anyway but now that it's happened I'm desperate for more or at least I was I mean it's seven years after the fact now at one point I just started assuming I would never hear more tonight music but I guess I'm glad they didn't let the rest of the decade play out in complete silence now we have seven more tracks 22 more minutes of material and while I like it I'm afraid fans of the last EP will not necessarily take two this one is hard not only because the musical trend tonight was born out of has trended downward a bit but also because Lunas and Moe have changed the sound of tonight up a little bit too for sure this EP is still very banger focused but the progressions are a bit more abstract this time around sometimes drifting off into these very bare-bones passages or even near silence in the case of first body it's like the duo's embracing these more deconstructed elements that are all the rage in the underground right now which I think it's cool that they're keeping up to date and they're experimenting and staying on the cutting edge but it's not always - the EPS benefit because of this the song first body that I just mentioned hit some pretty significant lulls along its runtime and even though I loved teasers from this thing like serpent for it's whooping manipulated vocals and wild drum circle percussion I know there were fans who are not really all that crazy about how long it took for HUD Moe and Lunas to really get to the meat of the drop on the song and again that's the thing about this EP it's nowhere near as direct as its predecessor and I know there are some people reacting to that as if this EP is bad or somehow significantly worse than the first one but I think what these guys are mostly doing on this project is playing with expectations and just employing some mind games for someone looking for something sweeter and hooky err on this EP I would listen to dollars it's got some playful vocal samples some rotund bass a rumbling B head banging drops and an engaging progression that keeps you on the edge of your seat what is not to like the song club finger true to its name feels like a weird twist on an EDM festival anthem with its thumping kicks and bright laser synthesizers I'm not gonna say the nonsensical vocal samples placed throughout the track aren't obnoxious because they are a little bit but I mess pretty heavily with these synced up synths bass and drums that hit at multiple points of the song it's hyper aggressive and absolutely ridiculous I prefer wonky ER glitch happier numbers on this record though like what it is the vocal samples are a lot more lighthearted the groove feels like something out of an old Neptune's bee I could even see Pharrell doing the weird auto-tune vocal it's placed at a few points of the song the song I'm in a hole toward the end of the EP is a hey it has some cool moments it's still a little underwhelming though with its tiny vocal samples and wash of synthesizers that kind of close up shop but I do think gimme some makes for a pretty bold finish the song is covered with this vocal sample this loud distorted disorienting those contrasts weirdly with these synth intervals that are distant and buzzy and erratic tonight building up these very skeletal passages into even odder grooves where these synths start progressing into these nonsensical melodies it sounds like a tangerine dream synth Odyssey but a lot more sour there are some indescribable II weird passages after this point I love the attitude I love the groove I love that it feels like tonight are basically giving middle fingers in every direction overall I thought this EP was a decent follow-up it's not nearly as adrenaline-pumping as the debut I mean it does go hard for sure that that's undeniable but it's a bit more cerebral it's a bit more about subverting expectations a few duds in the tracklist sure but there are more highlights than there are not also appreciating how most of these tracks flow into each other even the weird giggly skit after the halfway point look at the end of the day I hope we just don't have to wait seven more years for tonight to return with another EP or album but I guess I can sleep more soundly knowing that at anytime these guys can return with a fresh take on the banger I'm feeling a decent too strong seven on this one transition have you given this EP a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you liked please subscribe and please ah hi everyone Anthony sail tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new trippy red mixtape a love letter to you for this is the newest mixtape from rapper and singer trippy red the fourth installment of his a love letter to you series obviously and as far as rapper crooners go I have historically expressed quite a bit of faith in trippy red when it comes to speeding to the head of the pack making an impact on the emote rap genre he certainly seems to be on track with that with this tape set to do a hundred K this week however I've not really been all that excited about the man's recent output especially his new exclamation point record that dropped earlier this year which was easily the most low effort and just thrown together batch of songs the man has put his name on so far I don't know what creatively drove trippy red to this point but it was kind of a shock so much so that it's got me looking skeptically at this 21 track mixtape thinking how much effort did you really put into this very lengthy batch of songs nothing tells me you've put in the forethought to make any of these tracks have a shelf life longer than a year or even six months and do rappers at this point even expect their most hardcore fans to sit through these hour-long 20 track projects I went into this tape hoping that maybe trippy red would go back to basics a little bit given that this is part of an ongoing series that he is pretty well known for and give us a series of songs doing what we know just works emotional numbers trap bangers overly emotional singing sticky melodies catchy flows the opening track on this thing larae is not a very good omen though it sounds like a breakup text set to acoustic guitars loaded with all these fake deep quotables meant to make the other person feel like they're stupid for ending the relationship assuming it's their fault that ended it's not easy to sit through honestly and what's to come after this track is basically a mixed bag of snoozers losers bangers and anthems and tons and tons and tons of features to sum head-turners ynw Mele is on here post his incarceration which is pretty crazy and at the of all for me it sounds like there's this lengthy rambley vocal snippet from xxx tenth Osseo where he's kind of rambling on about his difficulties with I guess just being loved being in a relationship caring too much if you find that mindset sort of relatable even considering the person it's coming from but beyond that the feature list here is a gauntlet of basically whoever is hot at the moment to baby young boy lo mozi juice world which unfortunately I think speaks to a certain disposability when it comes to a lot of newer music which I think we're now just accepting as normal these very short shelf-life records with these feature lists that go in and out of fashion like seasonal wardrobes I will say the first leg of this tape starts off pretty focused though in true trippy red fashion with a lot of heart broken vocals and acoustic guitars and trap beats we have a song about wanting love we have a song about hating and not wanting love on the first leg of this tape trippy sounds more comfortable in this Lane than ever but that is also part of the problem because I think this puts trippy in a place where he is now just painting by the numbers delivering fans merely what they expect not expounding on these feelings or emotions in any way whatsoever granted who needs love does go pretty hard again it is a love rejection anthem with trippy openly embracing his single status the lyrics while they are pretty surface level they do sound like they come from a genuine place not so much the case for lovesick though whose constant references to forgetting what I said just feels like volunteering yourself for gaslighting not to mention the firework samples and the dramatic singing remind me of something off of Drake's first record - the hooks on love me more in real feel are pretty sharp but the verses are completely devoid of anything memorable not to mention the trap beat acoustic guitar combo is growing pretty stale at this point this emo trapped wave I don't even think is five years old and already we're running this instrumental style into the ground thankfully there are some welcome change ups with all the features to follow past this point this ain't that is certainly a highlight with some sparkling guitar peji O's and smooth bass sound tracking what is trippi's most effortlessly catchy hook in a while those saying that for real the saying that for real honestly I don't even mind the mediocre Lowell mozi feature in the second half six kiss by comparison is a much tougher listen though Meli's feature sounds completely tacked on juice worlds miniature versus nothing to write home about and then trippy pulls on some of the weirdest movie references that I think I've heard him drop in a while from Coraline to Megamind and also mentioning Optimus Prime yeah I can do without all that especially since trippy similes here are pretty boring the song ends with little yah T and P airborne sounds like a bad leftover from little yachties last record and on the track all for me smoke purp is so slathered in auto-tune he sounds absolutely ridiculous there are a lot of mediocre less than stupendous moments on this tape honestly I feel like all that's worth mentioning is the handful of highlights that happen past this point we have sickening with Tory Lanez which features some great pianos a little woodwind melodies too easily one of the more elegant moments on the tape trippi's refrains on the track of I don't feel too well a pretty hilarious considering the title of the song and lyrically he constantly references being sick or just sicknesses so I guess in a way it's one of the more focused songs here and then Tory Lanez feature goes a lot harder than I would have expected emotionally speaking so when he pops in it's not a lull or anything like that the Grinch is a very short hyper aggressive banger with more production from Pierre it's one of the wilder songs on here I wish there were more tracks that took this tone definitely would have made for a more fun experience but the moment that we have it is pretty good we have death featuring to baby while it is not one of his better features I've heard this year an appearance from the baby is always a bit of a pick-me-up on a project like this though the very nasty three 6 mafia's sample on this track goes a long way too with the trap beat and the club' synths on the instrumental it's a good vibe we also have bust-out featuring you've d considering the gorgeously melodic since on this track and the wonderful change-up on the chorus this has to be one of the tracks that has the most forethought on this tape because rarely on this project does a hook have this much contrast as a hook pop out this much I wish there were more tracks on this thing that had this level basic structure also you've D kind of one of the better features on the project a French rapper I wasn't aware of up until this point and he's really a breath of fresh air in this tracklist his delivery is pretty tight and his voice has a very distinct quality to it what also popped out was little wop on the jungle book and while I've never really been a huge lil wop fan up until this point his incredibly raspy delivery is cartoonish hilarious he sounds like twenty-one savage with a bronchial infection seriously though his very short appearance at the front end of this song definitely is attention-grabbing lyrically trippy goes at length throughout the rest of the track too definitely one of his more aggressively delivered sets of verses so that's that's a standout to the finish of the tape ends on a somewhat strong note with the acoustic abandoned and the boom bap ish can you rap like me we're trippy shows he can flow with old heads even if his pen game isn't the best now as much as I enjoy these tracks of course they are not enough to carry this hour-long project into a positive score because a majority of the material here is not all that great it's not memorable and all-in-all this project serves as a reminder that this is the current state of the music industry where songwriting barely matters just get a vibe get kind of a hook and a beat that sort of goes and you have a song just get it out there and maybe by some sort of fluke it'll hit at the very worst it'll get some streams on your massively long record and look I don't deny that there are artists out there including trippy red that this formula is working for but the problem is this formula is too easy to replicate and as a result of that you're not really leaving a mark a long lasting mark on your audience and it's going to be easy one day for another person to do exactly what you're doing and just step in your place records like this don't really foster long-term loyalty and you know what I hope I'm wrong about that I hope I'm wrong feeling a decent too strong for on this one transition have you given this tape a listen did you love it did you hate it but would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the life you like please subscribe please don't cry hit the bell is well over next to my head is another video that you expect him to drop an album like this frankly I think there are few electronic music producers out there who would feel bold enough to do so and I also think it's very cool that this record is reflective of Kai's obviously diverse tastes but does he recreate and embody these sounds in a way where I just enjoy them within the context of this record not really All Things Considered the new blood incantation project is a pretty good death metal record it has a great recording very heavy very brutal very crushing but everything rings through so clear the vocals the guitars the bass the drums really everything sonically and compositionally the band is a bit more progressive than your average death metal group some of the riffs and playing or a bit technical some of the song structures are winding and in really add to the flavor of these tracks and yet they never veer too far away from that classic and morbid sound now is every riff on this record great in my opinion not really and I think the 18 minute closing track is a bit convoluted and could have easily been broken down into a few different parts but still the material on here that is good is very good and I think is worth checking out for any metal fan really even someone who may be just curious about death metal and just looking to get a good example of how the genre sounds and in what its genetic makeup is I have been returning and returning and returning to this new Hot Chip record for months now really because it's it's been out for so long and honestly every time I listen to it it just feels more and more underwhelming less of it really sticks with me I'm just not really sure I mean Hot Chip has has never truly been one of my favorite indie tronic or synth pop bands but I've always hi everyone keeping it together here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Coldplay album everyday life this is a new full-length record from the world famous platinum selling rock band Coldplay they are back with their eighth full-length album it is a two-parter in 16 tracks that somehow comes in under an hour I'm gonna be honest with you this decade for Coldplay creatively I think has been pretty dismal Mylo ghost stories dreams not the band's best stuff and sure there's been a lot of commercial success and versatility and it looks like the band is doing well but the last album Coldplay drop that actually meant anything to me came out in 2008 so I went into this new record really hoping for the band to end things on a high note with this decade which was kind of easy it was easy going into this project with high hopes given the ambitious double album thing given teaser tracks like arabesque a groovy horn backed Jam expressing this sort of humanitarian oneness you could be me I could be you essentially asking the listener to put themselves in the shoes of people who they may fear or hate or think less of and not just this track but this entire record feels like a reaction to the incredibly intense and divisive times that we live in but also it lacks the equipment or maybe even the will to discuss the root causes of war and inequity and poverty and extremism so essentially Coldplay supplants a focus on real world problems and solutions for allusions to friendship a higher power nostalgia and a whole bunch of musical detours that just make this entire record feel like a crapshoot like on cry cry cry a piano back piece of vocal pop with a vintage flare sounds like it's something straight out of the 50s or 60s but now just coming out of an expensive studio today with some chipmunk background vocals that are really awkward doesn't really say much lyrically and the ending totally fizzles out for the most part it just feels like a random detour a total non song hit of Soma to distract from this records lack of core material and the odds and ends in the tracklist here continue especially on the second half a sudden elegant piano piece topped with a Persian poem that arrives after a very weird instrumental transition or the song broken a one-off gospel number complete with chorus of singers and finger snaps some humble piano - while it's on it's okay nothing horrible about it but ultimately it's another detour with a fizzled ending and a lack of reinforcement of everything that's going on around it the song guns that kicks off the second half is a fast and folky number maybe the most gripping and lyrically radical song of the bunch with some references to revolution and how our country politically prioritizes guns the singing and guitar playing on the track are great but the songs brevity leaves it feeling like a footnote amongst all of these bland non statements which the song also is sort of as well even though it's packed with more social commentary than many other tracks here these comments really fail to come together into any sort of focused statement I guess there are also songs here that just feel very off the mark like echo with its really pristine acoustics and its idealization of Africa as if it's just one big country singing about big rivers and African mothers taking this very assuring tone like everything's gonna be alright I'm not really sure about this one I feel like this is what you would get if you made Asura from Vampire Weekend right the most tone-deaf song he could even more tone-deaf is the single orphans which I didn't think too much of at first outside of it just sounding like a very dreamy arena rock ballad Ally u2 with its course about missing your youth and wanting to get drunk with your friends it doesn't seem like too much on the surface but it gets really awkward looking into the lyrics so the verses and the deeper meaning of the song as I guess they're inspired by refugees of the 2018 Damascus bombing in which case why is the danger these people are in their struggle to exist being juxtaposed against this chorus of no I fail to see the parallel here like what is the connection the matically if you just stare at the lyrics there doesn't really seem to be one what does this first world desire to gain your youth just ponder your youth and drink with your friends have to do with like not dying due to the misfortune of being born into a warzone I think it's really frankly stupid to portray their desires as just being like hey I want to know when I can drink with my friends in those moments I think their material needs and desires should be portrayed with a bit more accuracy not just some bomb-ass sing-along party course the band tosses in to make the song appealing for a pop audience and look there are definitely a handful of well-written well-structured and satisfying songs in the tracklist here arabesque champion of the world also trouble in town whose first leg sounds like a very low-key beautiful ballad that could have been on ghost stories but then it transitions into this gorgeous crescendo kicked off with a vocal snippet that sounds pretty Pink Floyd esque but this handful of tracks does not outweigh the immense amount of what sounds like filler on this record I'm sorry but there's no way that Coldplay could dig this record out of the mediocre rut it's in with more electronic classical gospel or whatever kind of detours everyday life is just a very well produced but unfocused album with a pretty incomplete message it's kind of woke on the surface but just as distracting and inconsequential as anything else the mainstream might want in front of your face feeling a light to decent 5 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you liked please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Coldplay forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new have a nice life album sea of worry this is the third full-length LP from dan barrett and tim mokuba's have a nice life a connecticut music project that somehow gained this incredible cult status after the release and slowly snowballing a claim of the 2008 album death consciousness with its 90 minute runtime fusing elements of post-punk with industrial music with drone with goth rock with low fine music shoegaze it's a pretty dark murky and soul-crushing listen with this heavy and raw sense of dread hanging over nearly every minute of the album in a way that was pretty unparalleled in the late 2000s by that virtue alone it's easy to hear why this stood out in the underground in the way that it did also why it's retained so much relevance over the years so since the release of death consciousness have a nice life output has been sporadic sure Tim and especially Dan have stayed busy with their own lives and side projects but the only other have a nice life album we have the speak of is the very good follow-up in 2014 the unnatural world and now see of worry which just dropped this month so given how rare have a nice life albums are and how good the first two records were I went into the third LP with pretty high expectations even if I wasn't all that crazy about the teaser tracks because with have a nice life there's a high probability that on first or even second listen you're gonna miss things because of the typically low fire recording experimental mixing layers of atmosphere and noise but with more and more listens through the seven tracks presented here sadly I found no such magic or even inner workings or details that really turn to this record around for me and in my opinion see of worry is by a mile the most stale and unimaginative project have a nice life has given us yet if there are two things that have really defined the appeal of the first to have a nice life record so far they are some pretty evocative sound play and also a seamless blend of dark experimental music genres that are just pulled together in such a way where it's hard to tell where one influence starts and another begins and it feels like neither of these things show up on see of worry as this record is just so painfully obvious which is made pretty clear by the opening track the title track of the record sea of worry what is this track it's a generic surf rock beat topped with some spooky whaling guitars very washed out and distant lead vocals that have kind of a snotty punkish tone and delivery to them it sounds like the breakout single from a gimmicky goth rock band that dresses like the Beach Boys while they have skeleton masks on or something I don't know the song writing is pretty formulaic the sound play is not all that exciting it's way more surface level than anything I would expect from a have a nice life record and I can't say the lengthier Dracula bells is that much better sure by comparison it's a more noisy abrasive and experimental track that works in numerous parts but very little of these parts land especially in the first section which features a horrendous drumbeat it's a kick snare snare with a rickety-ass hi-hat on every single quarter note the number of drum sets I've ever been behind in my life I can probably count on two hands and I can play this beat and I don't mean that it's a super simple cute little groovy beat that you might get out of a Meg white performance or a mode Tucker performance no it's just really stiff and boring and lifeless the dreary guitar intervals playing over the speed get pretty tedious too sure there's some pretty nice chord and melody change ups on the hook of the track but it's really not enough to save the song and then there's a portion where we suddenly break into this darker heavier more rhythmic and industrial passage with some buzzing bass some twisted lead vocals to cacophonous embellishments of piano and guitar kind of sounds like a paler version of something I might have heard on the new daughter's record and I'd like to say I enjoy the noisy crescendo that the track arrives to at the very end but the icy very synthetic I can't even describe them splashy scent passages that play over this wall of noise horrendous aesthetically they don't compliment anything going on underneath them and the way that they're mixed into the track they really overpower everything in an awkward way the song science B tones things down quite a bit by comparison and is another moment on the record that feels very out of character for have a nice life the track mostly sounds like a very anonymous New Wave demo from decades and decades ago with too much reverb on it we have some rigid and very sparse drums on this thing lightly pulsating bass then some faint tones that are so quiet it's difficult to make out exactly what they are part of the time guitars since the vocals are even more difficult to get a grasp of and I don't just mean lyrically which is typically the case for a have a nice life record but also melodically emotionally if the point of this track is for everything on it to be barely present then I would say mission accomplished now there is a passage in the second half where everything gets a little bit louder the guitars have a lot more presence than they did previously but it's it's really too little too late by this point the tracks grown stale at least for me and the progression it's arrived to is not all that gratifying we then have trespassers w-which kicks off with a guitar riff that shouldn't have been left on whatever Danko Jones or alkaline trio or hives record it was found on because I can't really say this but rocking riff really helps sea of worries case it mostly just sounds like an awkward attempt at being hooky while also failing to appreciate that the songs washed out production and ghostly aesthetic doesn't really do all that much for these forcefully vocals and fist-pumping riffs the song everything we forget is genuinely one of the few mums here that really feels like I have a nice life track that could fit on the two previous records feels like it's in their wheelhouse it's a layered and strange ambient piece that feels pretty massive there's so much going on and there's so much sound bleed happening it's difficult to make out every detail but it's like I'm hearing all of these cycling synthetics set against ghostly chorus vocals and maybe some strings either way it's equal parts gorgeous and unsettling even if at a forum in a runtime the whole thing is a bit breezy the sadly the record doesn't really pick up from here next we get a very sloppy loaf I piece of post-punk the instrumentation never really seems to coalesce into anything all that gripping it mostly just ends up being a noisy mess as the mix of the track just gets more and more distorted it's like a self-serious bass boost meme is it super abrasive yes but is it dynamic or texturally interesting not really it's like if a goth rock band with way too much reverb had about the same recording quality as like that 2009 waves record I assumed the closing track would be a pretty grand finale given its 13 minute runtime but the whole front end is taken up by this audio of what sounds like a television or radio preacher a really boring evangelist type who doesn't really have much to say honestly and don't get me wrong I'm not against the mention of Christianity on a rock record previously I've really enjoyed it especially when post rock bands have included audio of preachers who are really on some fire and brimstone shit but what our friend here is telling us on the tape about the devil and deception and so on and so forth can be heard by just about anybody if you flip on the Christian hour at your local public-access television station the only thing that could make me curious about this audio is if it was revealed that the guy talking is actually Pete Buddha judge and believe it or not there's a few points where their speech patterns are oddly similar once we finally transition into the more musical portion of this track it's okay we get some weary vocal harmonies and glistening pianos and light acoustic guitars I like the fat Dorjee display of instrumentation that comes in after this portion that's a pretty nice transition even if the lead vocals are turned down solo and buried into the mix so deeply it's almost comedic but yeah that's pretty much the end of the album and I gotta say this was rough this was not a very good record from the have a nice life even though it's been 10 years since death consciousness this is not the type of rut I would expect have a nice life to be and not on the third record I'm feeling a strong 32 a light four on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it but which rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry at the Bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana have a nice life but forever

hi everyone hose and II tell tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Maddie on record good faith this is the newest full-length project from French born songwriter producer electronic musician pop alchemist Maddie on I first heard of his stuff back in 2015 with the release of his debut album adventure the music on that project I wasn't crazy about it mostly just hit me like a very formulaic derivative EDM friendly brand of electro pop don't get me wrong there's some fun euphoric and even epic music packed into this record like the song okay or the track Imperium but be consistently boring vocal guests combined with the overall lack of interesting textures and the very synthetic to the point of sterile sound of these songs put me in a place where I doubted if I would ever be a part of the Madeon fanbase it's been four years since the release of that record though so I thought I would give his new one a fair shot just out of curiosity and a lot of suggestions from you guys of course and it's definitely a trimmer project at 35 minutes the production isn't really any less smooth than it was on the previous record but at least Maddie Ann's use of effects combined with the extra layering he throws into this record it makes for a pretty fantastical listen and the vocal features that are here on this project they fit pretty seamlessly into the album they aren't distracting they don't feel like they're driving a change in tone across the tracklist which makes for a more cohesive listen and not just all of that but the sweet sweet bliss he's able to conjure across this record makes it a cut above its predecessor on the opening track dream dream dream I'm not sure what's more attention grabbing is it the creatively chopped and luscious vocal harmonies or is it the cloudy bursts of enveloping sense that fill the mix with rainbows of color the vocals are a bit sleepy but I do like the robotic processing on them and makes it feel like I'm listening to I don't know an AI get in touch with its programmed emotions I get a similar vibe off the track be fine which even though it has a bolder groove hook your structure still lead vocals are very similar and they're also enhanced with these also gorgeous group vocal sections so at the start of this project already I am impressed more with what I am hearing than I was with any Madi on track so far not to say this project is perfect though there are points at which the vocals just don't really hit all that hard like the utterly forgettable closing track also on the track all my friends where the singing is so unblemished and nearly soulless that it's hard to connect I guess it reminds me of many lead vocal passages from Daft Punk's discovery but if you stripped out anything that was emotionally compelling I do love the dance grooves on the track though the cute little production details Madeon throws in here and there but still talking about the vocals the worst of which I think comes through on the track heavy with hoping which look to be credited to singer and songwriter Audra Mae someone who's worked once I listen to it she does not typically sound like this Madi on must have taken her voice and pitched it down in a way where it has this very awkward weird androgynous quality to it which is something I've heard done well before Dorian fucking Elektra but I can't say that's the case here on all these songs where I'm not crazy about the vocal Madeon is still bringing some instrumental heat some grooves which is also the case for the cuts where he features little vocals or no vocals at all like with the huge horn sections and fat hip hop beats toward the end of hold me just because which to my ears sound like John bel ian if John bel ian wasn't such a snoozefest too bad most of what happens up to this point of this track is a little bland we also have the track mania which is a beautiful arpeggiated synth Odyssey the introduction of the track features this primal drumming a rubbery and whimsical lead melody then we go full throttle with these heavy punchy beats when we're building up with these awesome synth arpeggios toward the finish it feels like I'm just flying up a mountain with my anime crew you know we're just make it stances then there's also the track miracle which features these bright shimmering blasts of group vocals just pitched samples that create this incredible feeling of euphoria it's like the rapture is hitting and I'm being brought up to electro-pop heaven with some slick grooves and tasteful progressions the introduction is another moment that feels a little Daffy Punk inspired with a side of Porter Robinson and a splash of Kanye West especially in the samples and drums and I would say the Kanye influence turns up one more time in a bold way on the track Nirvana after a dramatic vocal intro Madeon hits us with these thunderous drums bright just ringing synthesizers that feel like they're a product of the graduation era of course all of this is enhanced by these repeating vocal samples twittering high hats a hip-hop beat and I think Madeon makes it his own with these very glossy shimmery layers of sense that are very consistent with the bright futuristic and synthetic aesthetic most of this record shoots for so I love that Madi on on this record is able to effectively show off so many influences in a very obvious way while simultaneously creating a listen on this record that has a strong sense of identity to it that to me says hey it's fantastic that Madeon has a very strong sense of his artistic self which I still think is a work in progress because while the consistently glossy idyllic and euphoric sound that Madeon brings to the table is nice I don't find it to be all that versatile a lot of tracks on this project really pale in comparison to others especially on the vocal end and once more I think Madi on sound palettes really could use some more texture some shaking up and maybe cast a wider net of influences to pull from next time - overall though I thought this was a decent very likeable electro pop record with
