ah hey everyone anthony Fantan oh here internets busiest music nerd hope you're doing well and it is time for a review of the new gangster album one of the best yet together DJ premier and guru as Gangstar dropped some of the most essential hip-hop of the 90s had an amazing run through that decade in a way they helped evolve the genre out of its rudimentary golden age in the 80s with more nuanced jazzy instrumentation boom bap beats conscious lyrics and cold-blooded flows that were heavily influenced by the likes of Rakim now of course gangster weren't the only artists around this time pushing these ideas pushing the envelope in general KMD De La Soul Tribe Called Quest main source which are only a few examples but Gang Starr was as early to the party as almost anybody and certainly helped lay the groundwork for more hardcore sounds to come for anyone who happens to be out of the know DJ Premier didn't just produce beats for Gang Starr his production graced tracks from numerous classic hip-hop albums over this time period Mobb Deep's the infamous nas's Illmatic ready to die ARS ones return of the boom bap also jay-z's reasonable doubt gang stars transition into the bling era in 2003 with the owners was pretty good certainly not as bad as some of their other 90s contemporaries still primo and guru decided to call it quits around the halfway point of the decade and they both kept dropping music respectively that is until guru passed tragically in 2010 now it would be safe to assume with almost 10 years since that point the chances of a new gang star album are just non-existent but DJ Premier actually made it happen with an assembly of beats and tracks he's been producing and structuring topped with vocal recordings of grew that were laid around 2005 to 2009 it's pretty ambitious to make a brand new album not a compilation not a b-sides collection and album under these circumstances even with the best stuff at your fingertips how much workable material could prima have possibly had I mean after all one of the best yet is gang stars shortest record so far by a mile the tracklist is also slightly padded out with some interludes and there are quite a few features on this project too I mean I don't think there are too many features and I think a majority of the features on this thing are very quality but if you're one of those sticklers that thinks a record can't have too many other artists on it you might be unhappy with the number of guests and again I can't say the number of people on this record bugs me all that much because for the most part they all stay pretty faithful to Gangstar sound and vision whether you're talking about artists here who are essentially voices from gang stars past or new faces whose work is obviously inspired by gang stars legacy J Cole Royce to 5/9 and throwing it back we have jeru the damaja on here we have tallied quali on here q-tip mo P big hug credit to Prima though for doing his best with what I think he had access to because this thing does feel like a legitimately new album it doesn't feel like a bunch of warmed over leftovers it flows really well like an album should and he came through with quite a few highlights there's the track lights out with mo P who have had connections to Gang Starr for years the track is pretty much a perfectly crafted boom bat banger with chilling piano chords epic shots of strings also savage performances from both guru and mo P that lights out gang chorus lights out is incredible guru on this track not only as a killer verse but it's packed with a lot of good one-liners also a very good refrain to that one bar about rappers joining sag because they're actors I liked it the following track bad name which has grown on me a little bit since I first heard it is is eerily relevant given the current rap landscape the Primo beat here is basic but classic guru is resting on a pretty tried and true flow that seems heavily influenced by Rakim it's like something we would have previously heard on step in the arena and gurus bars on this track are essentially about hip-hop losing its spirit its fundamentals to materialism commercialism it's so relevant it doesn't feel like an old guru track but more like a broadcast from beyond the grave much in the same way many tracks on Bowie's black star fell I get a similar vibe from the tracks so many rappers later on the record which is essentially about the struggles of existing in the music industry one-hit wonders show business in general we have the track hitman featuring q-tip which topically is a bit of an odd detour the track is literally about a hitman a mercenary the instrumental on this one is equal parts grimy and theatrical it's like listening to the hip-hop equivalent of a short film q-tips refrain on this one is a little silly I wish he had a verse or something but the selling point of the track is really gurus verses which go into grave detail over how cold-blooded and calculated this hitman is he's secretive he's shadowy watch out all of these tracks all these moments contribute to a pretty quality first leg of this album there's no material so far that's as thorough or as creatively genius as mass appeal or tons of guns or a moment of truth but so far all of gurus lyrics are focused topical pretty well written even though these songs aren't super long I'm not coming away from most of them wanting more and I think a lot of that comes down to primo structuring these tracks as well as he does it sounds like primo put a lot of forethought into nearly everything going into this record and the same goes for most of the guests royce two five nine generally might not be one of my favorite rappers but he does drop one of my favorite guest verses on this project I love his expressive delivery I also think it's great how primo interacts with his needle drop line with that little record scratch and the second leg of his verse becomes this beautiful tribute to guru that line about his ashes being on the boards is pretty incredible also very impressed with Jay Cole on family and loyalty too I think he put together one of his best features ever on this one second only to maybe some of the stuff he's done with jid where he's really doing his best to try to keep up with him the drums on this one feel a little light a little dry almost like something that could have been on the owners but these super dramatic strings and pianos on this track are too pretty for words guru's hook is also fantastic talking about diamonds and using it as a metaphor for things that last or should last like loyalty family in a way it's kind of a shame it's been stashed away for all this time following this is maybe my least favorite track on the entire project get together which is an attempt at a smooth flirty sensual jam I think gurus bars on the track are pretty slick charismatic what I don't really like here honestly is Primo's very weak attempt at making a luxurious instrumental with these plinky keyboard chords that sound like a cat jumping off of a piano there's also Neos hook here which is obnoxious the line about this being as much Spanish as I know is annoying MIDI Scott on the track is fine not blowing my mind or anything but I understand the need for a female voice to sort of come in and play counterpoint to what guru is saying on the track and in for the most part I again I think she's I think she does well I think she does well it's just everything else surrounding her verse and gurus verse that is so painfully unlikable in the last leg I think the record starts to waver a little bit telecoil ease guest verse in my opinion is just sounding very off I don't know what it is about his voice that just doesn't sound him that soulful warm rasp that he's usually known for those smooth and nimble flows that I've always loved from his music in the past just don't carry over onto this feature he sounds like you sticks out like a sore thumb in the mix and not in a good way the track bring it back here features a very cool verse from guru but I'm not sure I really needed this to just be a 50 second detour you know what I mean it's it's one of the only moments on the record that truly feels like wow this you this is like literally just some leftover work here and you just tossed it into the record when you really could have built it out a little bit and made this album a bit more robust the track take flight is very good though with its orchestral samples with its features from Freddy Fox and big showed the track being the latest installment of gang stars militia series essentially calling back to the first one they did also with Freddy Fox and big Suge so kind of bring in a full circle and the song bless the mic is the closer here and it's a pretty interesting change of pace as the beat here is very Spacey very ambient gurus voice is treated in a way where it sounds like again I'll go back to that phrase a broadcast from beyond the grave it's like he's giving us advice or just giving us perspective from where he's at now after having left this plane of existence also it's utterly to have all of these samples of rock him bless the mic bless the mic bless the mic the track is obviously a tribute to gang Starr's legacy guru's legacy but obviously referencing back to another great MC - overall this thing was a very good project turned out way better than I thought it was going to give in its posthumous given just how long it's been since guru has passed away how long it's been since Gang Starr wasn't was a thing even if there are some weak moments here and there I think one of the best yet does stay very true to what Gang Starr musically stylistically philosophically was all about this projects a very good celebration of that and also the artistic era of rap music that Gang Starr came from I'm feeling a decent too strong 7 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Gang Starr forever

ah hey everyone a teeny bit tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new on amount of gucci album u.s.a yes this is the newest full-length album from chiptune and bit pop outfit Anamanaguchi and USA is their first record in about 6 years finally following up 2013's endless fantasy a project that at the time I was highly anticipating especially given some of the amazing non-album singles that led up to that point airbrushed mess my skateboard will go on aurora tracks that really painted a bright future for the bands fusions of pop rock and 8-bit music sadly endless fantasy despite highlights being on this project ended up being a little bloated one-dimensional I hoped we would get another record sooner rather than later but considering the previous Anamanaguchi album dropped in 2009 I guess I should have anticipated wait and it's not like the band to spent this entire time doing nothing in 2016 and 17 they did drop volumes 1 and 2 of their capsule silence 24 soundtracks they put out some singles Luke's knife city was certainly a little active either way Anamanaguchi is back now fully online with a new record and it's out via polyvinyl which is pretty cool the band has trimmed things back a little bit to a very manageable 14 tracks and 52 minutes I already went into this record loving the singles air online great teaser shimmering glitchy synthesis 1 manipulated vocal bits some thumping beats that sound like something out of a synth wave song and then some crunchy synth slap bass that feels like a Daft Punk relic it's an epic inspiring totally danceable electronic music composition and of course given some of the 8-bit tones and the synth patches the whole thing sounds incredibly video game music influenced specifically a golden age sitting between late era nes and early era n64 it's like I'm listening to the soundtrack to a 2d space shooter mixed with a racing game mixed with an excellent Japanese RPG we also have the equally good lorem ipsum which kicks things off with these eerie heavily processed lead vocals it sounds like a course of alien singing quietly into my ear but the song does bring another thick grand explosive display of 8-bit sense booming distorted drums as well but the percussion on this track sounds live and gets pretty aggressive too the track has an amazing build incredible melodies the whole thing sounds like I'm saving the fucking world with my closely knit group of super-powered anime friends we're all combining our lasers to create like a giant rainbow blast into an asteroid that's going to just crash into the planet and kill everyone the final climax of the track leads to this very dystopian droney ambient outro it's really intriguing especially when what sounds like ocean waves start creeping into the mix as well as some deep unsettling ghostly bass so between these two tracks these two teasers there there's a lot more versatility than there was I think throughout a great deal of endless fantasy so given that I was pretty excited to hear the rest of this album I dig the curious and strange intro that leads into lorem ipsum the slowly climbing and falling synth notes the digitized chance of u-s-a it's one of those introductions that works incredibly well just by virtue of being so weird you wonder what's going to come after past this point the band just keeps delivering one high-octane 8-bit banger after another the song CRT woods features these 50-foot high walls of burning synthesizers I'm loving the mix of sequenced as well as organic drums on this project it gives what on mana Gucci does a sometimes rigid and sometimes punky feel the mixing of all the synth layers on this track for as dense as they are is excellent I'm also loving just how nostalgic the tone of these since are just kind of hits me right in that gamer vein but this track and many others on here are still far from being purely an exercise in nostalgia as much as memory plays a role in the concept of this project because the heavy bass the punchy beats the panoramic mixing this thing is unquestionably a modern record the song sunset biplane is one of a handful of tracks here the features guest vocal in this particular case it is Caroline Lufkin I think her breathy vocal performance on this track is okay I mostly act by how her voice sounds mixed into the track in a way where it just feels like it's riding on top of the instrumental it's not in the thick of all the other instrumentation which makes the vocals feel despite how quietly sound overpowering in a really awkward way it's even worse on the track on my own featuring Hannah which by comparison I think is a much better tune with much better singing but once again the band just can't seem to get a good vocal mix on this project even with arguably the biggest guest on the project Hatsune Miku the legendary Vocaloid singer really software and in a voice bank but whatever Hatsune A's voice turns up all over at multiple points of the song PSX which is actually one of my favorite tracks on the project I love the slickly melodies on this track the bubbly 8-bit arpeggios and the driving riffs the Vocaloid bits do add a lot of character to this very aggressive track but they are amongst some of the quietest sounds in the mix you would think that it's it's a bit of a feature here that they would be displayed more prominently it's not the worst thing because that Vocaloid sound does tend to melt in with all the other synthetics in the track and it's still a high point on the project still a very energized and exciting and super catchy moment thankfully up to you with me she is the best balanced track vocally on the entire project the singing is very nicely laced into the rest of the instrumental which just makes it easy to enjoy the track sharp beats and richly layered synthesizers it's like rings of multi-coloured hearts swirling in every direction so even though some of these vocal cuts are the album's Achilles heel the highlights still continue the song overriding incorporate given this tracks video game since the very straightforward mid-paced kick snare pattern the epic builds this is like automata Gucci's take on an EDM anthem there's even something a little Porter Robinson about it but given Anamanaguchi has remixed Robinson's music before and I think Robinson is a fan as well that that just kind of makes sense we also have a few very glitchy cinematic interludes that add a lot of character to the flow of this project too whether it be a poofy neolite or speak to you even though it's longer than the other interludes here the tract tears well which does a really good job of setting the stage for the album's grand finale with these monumental synth layers that sound like a hundred orchestras just screaming on top of each other listening to it is like staring into the Sun and we also get a reprise of the us a chance then we have the tracks we die which is effectively the final moment of the album outside of the somewhat ambient outro LOM which I think does a very great job of resolving the album in a beautiful way we die takes its sweet time to evolve out of these fragmented synth passages a very soft beat begins to introduce itself and suddenly everything is following suit orbiting around that and immediately after this it's nothing but plucky 8-bit since roaring bass house inspired kick drums it sounds like if Zedd and Crystal Castles were taking turns beating Master Blaster and now they're finally at the ending credits overall it's a very strong finish to a pretty consistent and creative album which again did have some vocal mixing issues but nothing that derailed the entire LP but seriously what an accomplishment for Anamanaguchi this project is the record sounds and feels great I would say it's a must here for this niche genre and also there are qualities about this record that I think should lead to a transcending outside of the 8-bit world because the melodies the compositions the layering the mixing all around even if the aesthetic of this record is very specific they're really good fundamentals on nearly every cut here it's why I see no reason why fans of EDM or videogame music at large and be getting into this record also instrumental rock fans to don't miss out don't assume the whole 8-bit thing Pinzon amount of gucci on this record to a particular post or genre and that's it because that is merely the banner under which the group explores so many different sounds and styles I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you liked please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the links you subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Anamanaguchi USA

oh this new highly suspect album it's not good a highly suspect is a band out of Massachusetts and they've been active for a little more than half this decade now and their past couple of records they were just pretty much a straight alternative rock band sure maybe their last album was a little over produced but there was certainly nothing that was super stand out about much of what the band was doing the one weird totally unexpected thing was that they were signed to 300 entertainment which is primarily known as a rap label I mean some of the biggest artists on there include young thug Megan the stallion T Grizzly Reggie Snow is on there too Fetty WAP was on there as well again outside of that nothing particularly about the band's sound that would make you go WOW or would make you stop in your tracks I know that certainly was the case for me not amazing but certainly not terrible and I do get a lot of requests to listen to their stuff try it out so of course the man comes out with another record I am curious to try it and it is easily one of the worst things I've heard in 2019 and it's unfortunate because I could really tell they were shooting for this more mainstream widely appealing record where creatively so many different ideas and sounds and even features coalesce onto one very unlikely project I mean this thing features not only young thug but also Gojira the metal ah hi everyone droned any bone tanto here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the New Sun record pyro class this is a new record from the pioneering drone metal duo known as Sun a musical project that has been a defining force in the world of drone doom just drone music in general name something new and uncompromising ly heavy and I'd argue Sun has had some degree of impact on it the duo had an unquestionably amazing run in the 2000s things have more or less settled down since then but not completely with sun dropping a bunch of collaborative releases short form records like canon that weren't entirely made of new material it wasn't until this year that the band actually dropped a brand new project of brand new material with life metal this record also saw production from music legend Steve Albini and featured one of the richest heaviest and thickest sounds of any Sun record so far aesthetically and compositionally though nothing entirely new for Sun though I understand the option for simplicity on this one given just how great the recording was so life metal drops it's pretty good sounds great and shortly after the release of this record Sun announced another album around the corner pyro class basically more tracks taped in the same sessions but they're all stemming off of these ritualistically performed modal drones that the duo and their collaborators would engage in before and after recording sessions now given these are just timed improv essentially in a way extras one would go into this thing thinking that hey maybe it's not going to be that great maybe it's not going to be that substantive maybe there's not really much of interest here it's just extras but this record is actually really solid I will say that I enjoyed elements of this thing more than I did life metal the biggest issue I have with PI class truly and honestly is that it's kind of short at 44 minutes it's a fraction of life metals run time it's a fraction of the run time of many classic Sun Records but it still manages to be pretty engaging given the limitations of these improvisation 's and maybe their urgency as a result of that I think all the pieces on this record are a lot more dynamic and active than many of the endless soundscapes featured on life metal now of course these observations are really all within the context of Suns discography of course your average listener who's never heard of son before and has no idea what they do most of their stuff probably sounds the same and one track doesn't sound all that much more detail than another but as someone who's been listening to and enjoying and seeing son live for a long time I'm really digging this collection of tracks I'm loving the intro cut frost sea with its B steel guitar tone and harsh swells of distortion it is way more abrasive than most moments from life metal also in the mix what sounds like this otherworldly wind blowing up from hell and taking up a pretty large amount of space and the volume and textures on this track are very intense and just very huge they're moments on this song that sound like the entire world is just collapsing in on itself it's actually pretty incredible the material here was spur of the moment the drone reaches a point where it begins to resolve beautifully begins to get brighter opens up more space is in there the guitars start shifting chords pretty quickly much more quickly than one would expect in a Sun song and I love it quite a bit I'm just on the edge of my seat waiting for how these chords and and tones are going to resolve next on the track kingdoms following this the intro isn't that much different than I think your average son song or performance but in the thick of all these drones this Distortion these guitars it sounds like there are maybe some major scale melodies playing or just very righteous intervals fighting through this hellish haze it brings a bit of brightness to suns typically dark sound the following track which I hope I'm pronouncing correctly is it amplified ease either way it sounds like the Greek god of amplification the really does live up to its title with its gurgling skittering drones it's the first son song I've heard that I would dare call kind of glitchy there's a lot of subtle submerged noises hanging in the mix to that feel like they are obscured behind a wall of hideous mud either way they really pepper the main drone of the track with a lot of texture this track also hits a point where the tones that you're getting laced into the drone feel kind of serene there is a slow cycling rhythmic almost hypnotic quality to some of the secret sounds hidden in this drone that I like a lot and then there's the closer ascension whose drone is very odd it's like I'm listening to a bunch of tones individual tones lining up just coalescing and ringing in unison in a way where they feel like they are alien they're not of this world easily one of the boldest sounds on the entire record and pretty gratifying as an improvisation throughout overall for a Sun record I found pyro class to be pretty fast enjoyable direct not as major or as experimental as key records like monoliths and dimensions or the collaboration with Boris or black one but for me this one was anything but underwhelming a pretty interesting concept that yielded a lot of very engaging results feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana son forever

hi everyone sad the need a tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Earl EP feet of clay this is a new collection of tracks from mr. Earl Sweatshirt he dropped them just this past Halloween which is a move you can't help but read into especially given that it is earl will this be his darkest and scariest project yet after all the front cover does look more like something that would typically grace the front of a fiery black metal album a black goat sitting in the middle of what looks like a dimly lit forest this thing looks like it's about to ask me if I want to live deliciously I'm also curious about this EP drop in the Halloween connection given Earl's last full-length records some rap songs which came out last year and is unquestionably one of the most depressing hip-hop records of all time the lyrics Earl's dejected delivery his loose flows all over this project all of the enveloping instrumentals that make you feel like you're drowning in slow-motion yeah they all add up into a pretty depressing experience some rap songs may not appeal to most people but for anybody who's even had a brush with the types of emotions that influence that record you know so I went in two feet of clay mostly wondering are we going to hear more of that something else admittedly when I tried the track East from this EP I was pretty underwhelmed by it there were some elements of the track that I thought were likable the tight and mystical woodwinds sample that makes up 90% of the instrumental a few spare witty bars here and there the focus conceptually on the loss of loved ones but the production is very repetitive very OneNote not all that evocative and while Earl's rapping isn't terrible it's way too sloppy and rambley to feel musical song structure isn't much of a factor on this track either nor was it on most cuts from some rap songs though at least all of those tracks as a record came together effectively reinforcing each other each song on that project dragging you deeper into a depressive abyss in comparison feet of clay isn't nearly as cohesive for the most part I fail to see how these tracks really build on each other it's mostly like listening to bunch of random odds and ends that aren't very compelling the wrapping is too apathetic the instrumentals are too plain despite their low Phi and somewhat subversive pedigree beats from some rap songs like red water or nowhere to go had qualities about them that were intoxicating woozy oddly attractive despite how dark many of the album's core themes were I can't give the same compliment to most of the beats on feet of clay there are a few exceptions like with the track OD I love the grimy disorienting choppy samples on that track the instrumental sounds equal parts confusing and tragic and oddly enough this is one of the few moments on this project where Earl's wrapping is confidently metered and pretty consistent flowing very naturally it just happens to be over one of the most oddly shaped instrumentals in the batch this being pretty different from what we get on another track here and tomb where the vocals feel so disconnected from the beat why even have a beat at all it's like we're basically in spoken-word territory at this point now granted this track like many others here does have worthwhile lyrics they're still the strong sense of mourning going on though matically the 25 quarter to life bar was smart the socialite reformed alone every night bar was clever Earl also writing about still having bones to pick with his father which is continuing those mournful themes of this EP of some rap songs but still it's not enough to make this one a highlight there's also el Toro combo meal which features another instrumental i think is great there's these really haunting and maybe even pitched vocal harmonies or just a melody of some sort that sounds really ghostly in the mix also loving how choppy the rhythms are in the glamorous jazz pianos what I can't say is that the addition of Mavi a rapper who is obviously very inspired by Earl Sweatshirt was all that great of an addition to the track for the most part as he's rapping he just sounds like an angry or version of Earl it feels as redundant as having young thug and little baby on the same track at the same time I do think the really fat compressed heavily reverb vocals that Earl throws in into the second half of the track are pretty intriguing though one of the weirdest vocal placements I've ever heard Earl work into one of his projects I just wish this EP took more risks along these lines there are a few left-field ideas on the two-part tisk tisk and cookies as well the stuttering piano samples the weird transition at the midpoint Earl's rapping is actually pretty entrancing but still without stronger material surrounding this track in others here it doesn't add up to a whole lot the greatest disappointment on the record though is easily the closing track for n which is the longest here by a mile almost five minutes in length and has a Mikami feature on it and it's like Earl his guest and the instrumental are all in a competition to see who can be the least interesting the whole intro lasts about the length of half of the songs here then when Mikami does eventually come in it's like he's spitting these faux deep super esoteric abstractions they sound cool in the moment but ultimately are fleeting and lyrically Earl is pretty much on the same wavelength on this track and there are any number of rappers that spit along these lines that honestly I would rather listen to because they would show more focus and technical ability on a song like this whether it be Milo Billy woods blue uncommon NASA yeah feet of clay I'm pretty indifferent toward it I feel like in a way this project sounds the way that Earl must sound all the time to people who react to a project like some rap songs and say oh this this is boring nothing's happening Google I'm feeling a decent - a strong 5 on this one transition have you given this EP a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should i review next hit the like feel like please subscribe please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out and the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Earl Sweatshirt forever

ah hi every one month and he's stashed Hannah here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new swans album leaving meaning this is the 15th full-length album from experimental noise and post rock band swans michael gira and company are back after a short hiatus and a bit of a reformation leaving meaning is said to be from a new iteration of the band something post the recent amazing trilogy series of albums that they dropped this decade the seer which is uncompromising ly dark and harrowing the crushing and explosive to be kind and then the amazingly thick and transcendental the glowing man these records not only account in my opinion for some of the best material so far in swans discography but also some of the best rock music of this decade and after such a mind-expanding set of projects I was interested to hear where swans would go next as far as this being a new version of the band looking at the liner notes a lot of familiar faces are still in the mix here at some point even percussionist thore Harris all of the placements and involvement levels of each musician isn't 100% clear because the liner notes are a little jumbled but what is obvious is that this swans album much like every recent swans album feels like a huge communal undertaking with michael gira spearheading the whole thing we do seem to get some names outside of the usual swans powwow though ambient and electronic music artist Ben frost performs on the record singer and composer on Avon house wolf is here too even Jeremy Barnes and Heather trust of a hawk and hacksaw Fame which is a pretty amazing indie crossover that I would have assumed would happen earlier given their love of things like hammered dulcimer sonically and stylistically though leaving meaning doesn't seem like that much of a departure from what swans have been doing as of late the linear song structures the epic builds the intensity the mysticism the cerebral and hypnotic vibes that's all here again with a few variants across the tracklist the glossy tones on the track aniline guitars and sparse pianos on this track just Sparkle beautifully and elegantly and there also seems to be a bit of gospel influence in Michael Gira's vocal performance here in the chord progression and we hear the return of swans dabbling in gothic country on the song it's coming it's real prior to the release of this album I thought it was a great moment and now that I hear it in the thick of the entire record I still love it we also have the haunting and eerie vocal harmonies and creaking instrumentation on the nub which sounds like something out of a psychological horror movie or a witch's coven I also think the ritualistic and tribal chants on the track son fucker are thrilling also this song features one of the most grand instrumental progressions of the entire album with all these layers of hammered dulcimer and strings bells and what sounds like maybe accordion at one point the track transitions into this very steady sinister groove which for swans at this point is a pretty tried and true formula it's just done really well again here but as much as I enjoy the ideas on this record I feel are pretty new and refreshing across the album they're just too few and far between I think leaving meaning feels more like an album that is a reiteration for swan's more than it's an expansion with a handful of tracks failing to adequately progress compositionally across their six or ten-minute runtimes I guess I was a little naive going into this record thinking because it's 30 minutes less than a lot of the to our album swans has been dropping as of late then the tracks are gonna be more direct they're gonna get to the point but sometimes the expected climax the end or even in the middle of a song never really arrives and what we get as a result of that are just ephemeral ideas and maybe a lack of direction I mean even with enough one of the most texturally gratifying songs on the entire record the band never really puts a stamp on all this tension they're building up for the duration of the track and the last few moments are spent just giving us a drone that slowly dissipates into nothing I do find this album to be kind of a breeze in comparison with a lot of swans reefs and stuff it's it's actually kind of easy to get through despite it being 90 minutes it was also pretty simple making heads or tails of what moments and tracks appealed to me and which ones didn't and that's partially because I don't really feel like I'm listening to much of a progression or flow across the entire album I don't think these tracks reinforce each other all that well I don't feel like I'm wrestling with a large cohesively arranged beast as each track here feels pretty isolated and sectioned off and even though I think leaving meaning is a good is a solid is a likeable project they're just too many tracks here that again I feel like didn't climax in the way I would have liked or just didn't go far enough the song the hanging man for example sounds like the intro or the first leg to maybe a larger more consequential song earlier in the swans discography but instead it just gets tedious over the course of its runtime because it mostly relies on the same guitar lines again and again and again what few transitions we get aren't really that great or gratifying or tension releasing Gira's shouts on the track aren't even really as rousing as I would have liked I was somewhat underwhelmed to by cathedrals on heaven as well as some new things even though I do love the great groove and Gira's vocals on that track the tone of this song is impeccably sour and menacing but the track pretty much hits you with this same singular vibe and sound for all of seven minutes and I just feel like it could have done more my least favorite track on the entire record that was most likely the title track the vocals are way too washed out compositionally it is bland and the instrumentation for the duration of the track feels like it's constantly stuck in the state of I don't know starting or in trowing or just setting the tone but it never develops into something all that substantive or gratifying I'm happy to report though that there are more highlights on the second disc than there are on the first the nub it's coming it's real both of which I talked about in both of which for the most part I think are great the song what's this is a favorite as well I love the tribal drumming on this cut the folksy layers of strings to Gira's lead vocals feeling wearier than usual it's it's a very somber song enchanting - and the sparkling crescendo that's offered to us in the second leg of the track is fantastic it's one of swans most mellow and wondrous acts in a while and we also have my phantom limb which is a manic and disorienting closer with all these jeera vocal layers where he's shouting and ranting some of the vocals are deadpan - in a way it reminds me of very very early swans like filth and cop era swans but without the same primal noise rock Rivage even though instrumentally it sounds very much like a modern swans track I feel like that old framework of their stuff is still there overall I think this is a pretty good album from swans there was only one track that I really disliked and most of them I thought were pretty good and there were a handful that hit me as being just a little middle-of-the-road kind of predictable so-so not pushing the envelope in the way that a lot of swans recent work has and that certainly doesn't mean they're bad especially since it sounds like they still took quite a bit of skill and forethought to compose and perform I just can't tell you this record is as grand or as ambitious or as large in scope or as transcendental as swans past three records it's far from one of their worst though and certainly worth listening to if you've been a fan of everything swans has been doing up until this point especially the recent stuff I'm feeling a light too decent 7 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video for you to check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana salons forever

last year when Kanye was hitting us with so much not immediately after scrapping what sounded like it could have been a pretty decent project in yandi and if that record got scrapped because of a new creative direction because of Kanye wanting to make godly or music how was this not the original plan I mean after all Kanye has been using these Sunday service performances and the embrace of Christianity as a bit of a public IRA demson arc for most of this year I assumed his next project would be or gospel inspired as early as April either way the album we got is the album we got and Jesus's King sounds like again we're basically in the same place we were on yay even with the intended change in sound and topical focus I really don't feel like Jesus is king as the gospel album that Kanye has been building it up to be even with all the references to Jesus even with him completely avoiding swearing it's really more of a record about Kanye's personal faith as a Christian than it is about God Jesus or anything related to those things big picture but it's not really revealing on that front if we're being honest I think what this record reveals more than anything is more about Kanye's mental health so in a way Jesus is king is a record about one thing that is actually about another thing and not in a way that's conceptual or deep as I think Kanye's ego makes it difficult for him to focus on the topic at hand without him making it about himself case in point the track hands on and there are elements of this track that I like I like the glitchy and heavily manipulated vocal passages I like the ice-cold synth swells I like how eerie and minimal the instrumental feels but I can't say I care for the lyrics on this one at all especially as Kanye gets into people criticizing him for making a gospel album and and how Christians are judging him there are like 2 billion Christians on the planet the ones that are even aware of Kanye's shift in style and theme most likely have a wide range of opinions on it and the ones that may be showcasing a slightly judgmental attitude might be doing so because they're looking at the wider context of Kanye's past I find it funny that Kanye would bring up hypocrisy in this instance when I mean the man is no stranger to hypocrisy himself either way it's annoyingly reductive and egotistical to act as if Christians at large are against Kanye's new shift and message not to mention I see this track as a part of a pattern on this record of Kanye using his faith in a way to indulge his persecution complex I'll be the first to acknowledge the public can be pretty hard on Kanye but going as far as to create parallels between himself and the treatment and betrayal of Jesus Christ on the tracks Allah which in my opinion is one of the better tracks here that seems like a bit much in fact a whole lot of much not only is it probably a tad bit blasphemous but on top of that I'm pretty sure in the end even Jesus himself was saying Father forgive them for they do not know what they are doing the underlying attitude with Kanye's message here feels more like a middle finger the same one he pulls whenever he's told not to focus his creative energies in a certain way and there are multiple spots on this LP where Kanye admits to not really being christ-like yelling at the chauffeur yelling at his dad on the track follow God which again makes me feel like this is less of a gospel album and more of an album about Kanye's own personal interpretation of Christianity which of course is molded in the image of his flawed personality I mean maybe this is a very obvious point but let's look at the very popular Matthew 19 24 you know the one about it being difficult for a rich person to enter the kingdom of heaven despite that yayyyy justifies the prices that I charge on the track on God as if it's a virtue or something I'm sorry but I don't think overpriced merchant shoes are what's standing between Kanye West and his family's starving I mean the Kardashians are pretty much set for life so there are a lot of complicated layers on Jesus's King ones that I'm not even sure Kanye was intentionally trying to work in here if he was I don't think the lyrics would be so reductive half the time I don't think the production would feel so rushed because even though Jesus is king is rough around the edges and short just like yeh was I feel like we're only getting a fraction of the effort and the self awareness now this is not true of every track on the project again the cut Salah is fantastic production is incredible the gospel choir sounds amazing the chilling organ chords the building instrumental Kanye's steady authoritative rapping push a tee very clearly has a co-writer credit on this one without even looking especially during the last verse that sounds like it's it's very much a push of t flow push it to you wordplay huge presentation amazing performance easily one of the best songs here and as long as I'm talking highlights on this thing we have to mention use this gospel featuring not only Kenny G but also the reunion of clips which is pretty fitting given that Pusha T's brother no malice formerly malice is now a Christian rapper we have some beautiful singular keyboard notes on this track those classic those trademark warped Kanye vocal harmonies solid vocal line from Kanye starting the entire track off the lyrics for him are a bit general with mentions of angels and heaven and so on and so forth but still it makes for one of the more powerful moments on the project the push of tea and no malice features on this track are pretty short but they are really good especially the no malice part of the the track his lyricism there is impeccable and I think in a very brief way he goes over his own transition into being a more faith oriented artist also the elegant sax solo at the end is great and the way the beat comes back in and the very last leg of the song it's a cinematic so great track I mean I wish nearly every song here featured as many fantastic musical and lyrical elements as great a structure and truth be told there are elements of other songs here that I think are good like the groove and the flow on follow god I wish the song developed more but I think the energy on this one is like a mix of Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy and yay also loving the bright shots of keyboard on the track on God ty dolla sign's vocal harmonies on the track everything we need are also great but a majority of tracks on Jesus is king just leave me with a mix of either disappointment or just wanting more whether you're talking about closed on Sunday which starts off very dramatically with those acoustic guitars the pom-pom choral vocals but come on man closed on Sunday you're my chick-fil-a number one with the lemonade are you kidding me hold the selfies put the gram away look out for vipers don't let them in doctrine eight which is not only an instance of projection on this song obviously but the lyrics on this trackers so silly and just do not fit the tone of the instrumental or the song at all how am I supposed to take this seriously second silliest on the project might go to when I thought the book of Job was a job and even though there are elements of on God that I like what I don't care for is how weak the rhyme scheme is how one-dimensional the song structure is how slovenly Kanye's delivery is on this track it feels like more of a rough sketch then some of the cuts off the yandi bootleg meanwhile the track water has maybe the worst instrumental on the entire project the splashy little chords the clunky synth bass it sounds like a bad animal collective demo meanwhile the opening vocals just sound like Kanye meandering riffing the singing is not good at all and not that Kanye is an amazing singer just sounds like he's not really trying all that much here like he's just kind of throwing something out there again another moment that feels like he's kind of spitballing and maybe would ever find it if he were in a better place and willing to take another pass at it down the road then we have the almost monotone verse of Jesus do this Jesus please that which honestly to me comes off more like a dependency than a prayer granted the gospel vocals on the track sounds stunning just like they do all over the rest of the record but they just don't make up for the bad performance and lack of direction on this one especially that the last 40 seconds of this thing feels totally unnecessary the song God is is basically Kanye giving a very blemished vocal performance over a pitched gospel sample it's a song on the record that kind of reminds me of ghost town from yay and not necessarily in a bad way I mean the the parallels that I see between these two tracks are both positive ones I think if there's any song on this project that displays Kanye's faith in an endearing way it's this one but it still doesn't change the fact that to me the song feels like I'm just listening to overblown karaoke the opener and the clothes are on this thing I like the vibe of both of these tracks but I'm not sure what the benefit is of providing us with these really short snippets one being the intro that is basically a clip of the Sunday service choir doing their thing out of what sounds like what could have been hours of audio when it cuts in it's like it's been going on for minutes prior and when it cuts out it's like the recorder just stopped again like what they were doing but it didn't really flow in in a way that felt like ah this is an intro it felt like oh this is like a weird snippet and it only finishes because where it was going was left on the cutting room floor the sonically Jesus is Lord in my opinion feels more like a fitting intro with beautifully layered horns and lyrics that would be a pretty good tone Center for just about any Christian album but it just ends abruptly before even a minute I don't really know what to make of it just like much of this record honestly it's kind of cool while it's on and I get that I can play it over and over and over to get that vibe again if I want I guess but I don't think I really get enough of it to really make a call on it so - I guess just stick a fork in it I I don't really care for this record and what's really hard to acknowledge right now is that I feel like we are at a crossroads with Jesus is king we're really standing at what is either going to be a weird creative detour for Kanye that will just pass on into something else and the whole to do about him being born again and only making Christian music now will seem even sillier in retrospect or we are potentially staring the end of Kanye's career in the face here because I don't think Kanye's career can handle four more records like this and by like this I don't mean a Christian album if Kanye continues to make gospel music I would love to hear him drop a record where he sticks to the Christian ethos more effectively and not just use it as a throughway to air out other grievances I would love to hear a longer more sensibly structured project with better songwriting less skeletal instrumentals - I mean for a Christian album this thing again is not very christ-like nor is it very a boom like I'm feeling a strong four to a light five on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should our next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Kanye West Jesus is king forever

ah hi everyone ghoul that he's spooked a now here the Internet's creepiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new clipping album there existed an addiction to blue this is the newest record from experimental hip hop trio clipping clipping to this day features the production and sound design of William Hudson as well as Jonathan Snipes and of course the rapping and the storytelling of mr. Davi Diggs now since turning heads and turning noise rap on its head in 2013 with their mixtape mid-city the trio has consistently proven themselves to be one of the most creative acts in hip-hop today whether it's through their spectacular Sub Pop debut a year later or with the narrative concept album splendour and misery in 2016 a record about an escapee on an intergalactic slave ship and the ship falls in love with him it's complicated anyway it's been a few years now since we have heard from clipping in a studio album capacity though it seems like each members kept pretty busy with their own respective solo projects in film work soundtrack work some solo stuff too but despite each member being split into their own lane for a little bit they have convened on to this new record in such a way where it sounds like they just haven't missed a beat because they come through with one of their most cohesive focused conceptual and Big Idea records yet now there existed in addiction to blood isn't that far off sonically and thematically from a lot of clippings previous work there is a lot of storytelling on this thing a lot of very fast verbose rapping the production is noisy vaguely industrial at points but above all this new album here is scary it's frightening it's kind of the linchpin of the record one could potentially classify this project even as horrorcore with it's morbid infatuations all of its blood all of its gruesome details so yeah there's a lot of bodies buried on this album it's kind of creepy though again for clipping that is not entirely new what our tracks like body and blood or break the glass if not attempt at inducing fear but basically that whole fear thing on there existed in addiction to blood they push it so much further it is the focus of the album they are dropping this project just before Halloween for Christ's sake there are lyrics on this thing referencing bad horror movie plots and jump scares also pretty much every instrumental on this thing feels like an overt nod to horror movie soundtracks both new and old whether you're talking about the heavy and droning Club down or the track nothing is safe whose persistent pianos and synth sound very John Carpenter inspired also you have some of the interlude cuts on here such as haunting which is I think a very old vintage tape of a woman describing herself as being haunted by Satan her descriptions are pretty unnerving and then there's also possession which sounds like a audio clip from an old horror movie it's very campy a little corny but still adds to the character of the record so the trio's appreciation of horror as an art form as a medium of expression is very much on display on this project but even though again I think you could effectively categorize this record as a horrorcore album there's very little about what inspires it that seems rooted in horror core as a genre there's not a whole lot here that sounds like or reminds me of old three 6 mafia or the Memphis scene back in the day in general Brotha Lynch hung or ICP or grave diggers and not that I think clipping has anything against those artists they probably enjoy a great deal of them but clearly the sound and style of this album is a lot less about horrorcore as a music genre up until this point and more about trying to embody expressions of horror especially in film in their own way on this record in such a way that it leads to a unique and almost cinematic experience which shouldn't be too surprising because when you look at the background of the trio you have soundtrack work you have acting you have writing you have sound design there are numerous tracks on this project just like with splendor and misery where Dobby does rapping speedily over these mostly drum 'less instrumentals that have huge atmospheres huge droning bass again with the track club down the massive hits of industrial noise on the song are huge the song he dead also features very little in terms of rhythm but still there's lots of eerie droning tones on this track distant metallic bangs the IDI balloon chorus is great and the instrumental on the show features all of these metallic glitches and distortions occasionally bringing in some handclaps to shore up the pace of the song though I will say this isn't one of my favorite tracks on the record compositionally and it's one of the few moments here that makes me wish there were maybe some more traditionally musical elements placed here and there on the record just to break things up and just add it a bit more sweetness even if it is bitter sweetness especially on cuts where WT is bringing the most head-bobbing flows but still I do love the storyline on this track which seems like it's about a torturous murderer who's breaking bones and cutting skin and sawing off shoulders and I guess he's subjecting other people to all of this it's it's almost like a saw in a way but what else would you expect from an album that puts you face-to-face on the cover with 49 nails just pointed right at you like you're stuck in a death machine even more challenging those the track all in your head which features all of these deadpan refrains from dahveed wild hurried ranting from counterfeit Madison thumping sparse rhythms metallic clangs lots of synthetic noise but then there is this chilling dusty sad chord progression that introduces itself and we get this wonderful vocal passage from Robin Hood it feels like the Sun coming up after a long dark night of everyone just slaughtering each other in the streets it's bright out it's a new day but then all the blood and all the death and all the mayhem is is revealed not crazy about the first portion again but I do love the singing on this portion of the track feels vaguely gospel inspired too it's easily one of the most powerful moments on the entire record the song attunement sees dahveed putting more of his flows over these industrial sounds more heavy bass more noise more fast rap flows which i think are great i also love how the numerous references to burning on this track lead us effectively into the album's final cut the 18 minute long piano burning which sounds like a field recording of a piano burning and that's it for 18 minutes still another track with the same instrumental type as attunement does make me wish there was a bit more sonic variety or just variants across the record I guess the song does still add to more of this feel of the the sound design of this record feeling akin to that of a modern horror movie trailer but a bit harsher a bit noisier almost as if the people crafting the trailer listened to a lot of Whitehouse or perience or MERS bow or maybe even some throbbing gristle thankfully the more accessible cuts on this record of which there are plenty are consistently great and versatile again the track nothing is safe which is essentially about a trap house a trap spot which ends up being under siege everyone thinks they're locked and loaded they're safe nothing's gonna happen they're protected that does not end up being the case though and the carpenter' inspired instrumental and the tense rapping and storytelling from dahveed just keeps you on the edge of your seat we eventually reach a point on the track where we have these panoramic layers of scents tight trap rhythms also the track key dead which again at balloon kicks off perfectly his singing and the melody almost reminds me of an old young father song but overall the vibe of this track is a lot droney er a lot creepier dahveed's intense rapping on this track basically flips an all-too-common trope in today's news police brutality depicting a police killing almost as if you are being chased down by monsters by almost werewolf like creatures who are going to kill you the track la mala ordina is a somewhat weird change of pace given that the that buzzy lead synthesizers and dusty lo-fi drums sound like something off of a black moth super rainbow record it's a little kooky the track also features guest verses from metal candy as well as Benny the butcher and if you're familiar with those two rappers you can see why obviously W would use this as an opportunity to take a lot of themes of violence and drug dealing and do a bit of an eerie flip on that also I should mention that the last minute or so of this track is really just a harsh wall of noise and it is fucking awesome and as long as we're talking about features on this thing my favorite is probably let chats off the track run for your life chat basically plays a a killer cur grimy southern flow and twang adds a refreshing dynamic to the tracklist also I have to talk about how genius the production on this track is all the found sounds and field recordings give you the feeling of the protagonist being outside existing in the space that they're rapping about also there's a moment where a beat swells under dahveed's voice that he's rapping in time with but the beat arrives by way of a car driving by which is like one of the weirdest and most insane ideas I think I've ever heard worked into a hip-hop track but is oh my god amazing though this really thick bassy beat pops in when chats feature pops in later on the track in full and it sounds fantastic I love that we get this slow transition to slow progression to this point that is so fulfilling it's so gratifying the song blood of the thing I think is really where the album's title and main theme gets explained pretty thoroughly with dahveed as a protagonist explaining the society the context that he lives in basically having this infatuation this desire to consume violence murder and this also comes along I think with a commentary on normalization as well because it seems almost as if at points on the song davido is trying to escape the blood escape the murder but then he's almost being indoctrinated into it like a cult love the sputtering beat on this track the really prominent and strange esoteric vocal samples the dusty chants in the background as well Debbie eats flows just dart in every direction and are impeccably executed I guess I should also mention the track story 7 which for longtime clipping fans is another addition to the story series every major clipping project so far has had a story song on it and they usually end up being a highlight of some sort and occasionally they even reference each other the story on this record though still plays into the murderous and creepy fantastical and ghoulish themes of the record though as this story is essentially about a woman who turns into a beast I'm assuming a werewolf because there's reference to a there being a full moon on the track and she's basically killing men that she's seducing she runs into a character from a previous story that clipping has done though I'm not going to spoil too much of the story beyond that the instrumental on this one is really odd though the transitions are breakneck and don't even seem logical but the more I listen to it the more I found it to be incredibly catchy how did Orion glitchy and occasionally harsh it is almost remind me of moments off of clippings wriggle EP which is not necessarily a bad thing as I think that's one of their more interesting projects overall though I think this is yet another great album from clipping a few tracks that I thought paled in comparison to others along the tracklist sure maybe the final cut is a little excessive with it being as long as it is but I still think this project showcases a lot of great rapping storytelling production and sound craft great theme and concept even if it makes this album maybe one of the more niche records and clippings discography but still I see no reason not to make this record a tradition in your yearly Halloween music rotation though I would not call this a Halloween album though it just happens to be a horrifying scary record that clipping smartly dropped near Halloween so people would kind of be in the creepy spirit that's just good marketing okay it's just good marketing everything else about the record though is good music even if occasionally I think clipping does go out of their way to sacrifice some of the musical elements of this record and even with their last record a little bit too just so the narrative shines a bit brighter but given how unique intriguing and entertaining clippings narratives typically are it is a compromise I'm totally fine with I'm feeling a light too decent eight on this one transition
