hi everyone nice the need a tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Caroline Polo check record pang this is an album I've been tracking ever since the release of Caroline's single door which was dropped this past June and every song she has teased us with in the lead up to this record has been good or great what sounds like a futuristic and progressive take on art pop Peng was shaping up to be one of the more promising albums of the year and while it was unfortunate to see the demise of Caroline's former band chairlift in 2017 I would like to hear her move on to greener pastures with a solo effort and that's exactly what pang is and does it's pretty hard to deny just how sweet cleanly produced and fantastical many songs on this record are it's like I'm listening to bits of Charli XCX meets alternative R&B meets Kate Bush meets maybe some top 40 music in 2019 and that direction shouldn't be too surprising considering some of the people producing this thing people like Andrew Wyatt of Mike snow as well as AG Cooke and Daniel Horrell of the PC music camp together they handle the bulk of the production on this record the future of pop is here and it's PC so I was pretty psyched to try this thing however I was a little scared by the initial moments of the record which I don't think are all that great not at the quality level of singing and songwriting I was expecting given the singles the intro cut the gate is very smooth but it's about as fulfilling as an exchange with a Walmart greeter it's short and by the time it's over I realized I've got nothing out of it and after this a few bland cuts like the title track I like the angular since that play throughout many passages of this song but the tone and the energy of this track is just way too subdued for the start of an album this is more like a cool down moment on the back end of a full-length record not to mention the song features one of Caroline's most underwhelming vocal performances - and the song new normal the beat on this instrumental just sounds like a cheap attempt at working some foreign flavors and rhythm into the record that didn't really need to be there especially since they they kind of clash with these strange country-fried guitars that pop in here and they're just sliding in with a touch of distortion I think the record continues to get better from here though the song hit me where it hurts is a really effective attempt at working some glamourous R&B into the project Caroline and Wyatt put their own weirdly minimal spin on it I love these soaring vocals and rich chords on the hook I like how disjointed and sparse the beat is behind the verses there are also hits of background vocals at some points on the track - that almost feel like ad-libs it's really like I'm listening to deconstructed R&B the song I give up features more solid tune writing as well as very fractured sparse rhythms the vocals on this one are raw very naked but so angelic and how bare the verses are just makes the choruses feel even more you work with that rush of background vocals and bass when it finally hits now look all of this is good so far we have some momentum going in the tracklist Caroline's vocals are sounding great well-executed expressive mature but something you should anticipate with this record is that the whole thing is very very very low-key very moody - this is not a snappy pop record which is something some people might have assumed going into this project given some singles like so hot you're hurting my feelings the vibe of the track is pretty smooth but it's honestly the most high-octane moment on the entire record so if the shiny synth chords and lightly distorted guitars in the background of this one are not enough boom for you you might not dig on this one I don't really see the lack of fireworks on this record as entirely a bad thing though especially given how gorgeous and enchanting nearly every song here is you have the dreamy and acoustic look at me now the vocals really sell this one it's so elegant and elements of it reminded me of breezier jangly or more euphoric cuts from the Cocteau twins discography meanwhile the dark subterranean bass on insomnia paired with the bright futuristic synth tones and vocal harmonies feels like taking PC music aesthetics and applying it to like an ambient pop blueprint the song ocean of tears was a great single in the lead-up to this record I still love hearing it in the midst of this record and the more that I listen to it I swear to god they're elements of this track aesthetically that kind of remind me of Travis Scott's 9:02 uh no off of rodeo it's the atmosphere it's the small hits of auto-tune ad-libs in the background it's the singing that sometimes reminds me of Casey Hills it's also the punchy beat while again I do think there are some esthetic similarities the tune is vastly different very heady but very catchy which is part of the course for most of the tracks on this record while this is certainly a pop album it's structured like a pop album it is hooky like a pop album there's something about the mood the tone the vibe of the whole thing that just comes off very cerebral the beautiful songs and the tracklist keep rolling with hey big eyes also go as a dream although I don't know how much I care for the intro on this track which in pure PC music fashion is auto tune sounds alien almost as if a cyborg or an AI is singing the song and I think that's something that works with most artists who work with Danny work with Cooke work with even Sophie and are deeply embracing all these futurist sounds and visuals but for the most part it makes this track stick out like a sore thumb not in a great way because a lot of the songs up until this point feel pretty organic at least vocally one thing I do want to point out is some of the background vocals on the song the ha ha ha which I see is a very conscious Laurie Anderson shout out appreciate that I think the song Caroline shut up sticks out for much better reasons though there's quite a bit of swagger on this track vocally even though the song is about expressing doubt in the realm of love and wanting to quell that so Caroline sings to herself when she's filling her head with these ideas can a line shut uh the track isn't 3/4 and I think it does a great job of taking the stereotypical blueprint of an old-school spacious waltz II type of ballad with lots of drama and applying some modern synthetic elements to it the songs door and parachute make sure the entire album ends off on a really strong note back in the city I'm just another girl in a sweater yeah pang is just another great forward-thinking quality produced and super catchy thoughtful pop record in 2019 granted it's not the most innovative or consistent record in this style that I've heard this year and I think the tracklist mostly runs like a bunch of disjointed ideas not really any overall themes or concepts on this thing at least to my ears though a lot of the tracks do seem to center around love personal connections and emotions and as I mentioned earlier I think the album's initial moments are not quite as strong as the album's final moments but a vast majority of these tracks these 14 tracks are are pure fire and I can only hope that Caroline's efforts from here grow more ambitious thematic as well as focused although I can't say I'm complaining too much right now because as is this is really great feeling a light to decent 8 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should i review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is a another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Caroline polo check forever

hi everyone Bethany coughed anno here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new lightning bolt album sonic Citadel legendary noise rock duo lightning bolt Bryan Chippendale and Brian Gibson they are back following up 2014's fantasy Empire for over 20 years now the Bryan's have been creating some of the most delightful sonic mayhem within all of noise rock with just drums and bass mostly together they had been responsible for some of the most crushing and psychedelic records in the genre from the 2000s really of all time wonderful rainbow Earthly Delights also hyper Magic Mountain a record that I love despite the fact that more often than not when I listen to this album all the way through I get a head splitting migraine it's sad that in recent years Lightning volts output seems to have slowed down a little bit the new stuff is not as aggressive or as explosive as the old stuff however I would love to hear a record we're lightening both is capturing their former glory once again and I gotta say sonic Citadel is a pretty welcome addition to their catalogue and astonishingly they don't achieve this by pushing their sound to another level of insanity lightning bolt actually reels it in a little bit on this one not hitting listeners with as many frantic finger taps on that bass neck not as many overdubs or layers or loops it's like the Brian's are breaking it back down to the simplicity of the wonderful rainbow era from here the duo starts delivering songs with clearer structures a bit more melody a smidge of method two lightning bolts usual madness Chippendales vocals on this record feel a lot less like a demented person yelling at you through the talkbox of a McDonald's drive-thru and more like somebody who's really trying to hold a tune under that occasionally Gibson's bass riffs are a little steady follow a very straightforward chord structure whether you're talking about whose skirt don't or Don Henley in the park especially all insane now this shift in tone is not amazing from front to back on the project personally I think some of Chippendales vocals can feel a little tedious these singing on USA is a psycho is just okay while the melodies and head-bobbing grooves once again on all insane do get very repetitive very fast for the most part this track is a really straightforward rock song and while I do admire lightning bolt for trying it I don't know if a track of this style is really in their skill set especially since the recording and the mix doesn't exactly show the dynamics that maybe a four piece or a five piece would display playing a track that is equally as simple thankfully this more melodic shift in tone benefits more tracks on the album than it doesn't the track Husker don't is easily one of my favorite lightning-bolt tracks ever now Chippendales vocals on this one have a classic punky quality to them the bass tone and usual lightning bolt fashion is grimy as hell and I love the just cascading raining down of harmonized fiery screaming bass leads that pop in in between each verse also the way the whole thing shits around the second half with that amazing epic descending bass line is great not to mention the de-evolution into just disheveled chaos for the last minute or so the song Don Henley is almost meditative in a way with Gibson playing his bass at a very high pitch and with these lines these chords these phrasings that are very jeroni it's almost like he's playing a sitar especially toward the start of the whole thing where his bass is sounding particularly thin and jangly it mostly evolves into a mess during the last leg that when it could have gone somewhere more interesting now while sonic Citadel does show a slightly sweeter side of lightning bolt no doubt there are still plenty of tracks here that sound like the soundtrack to a hailstorm of asteroids breaking through Earth's atmosphere unscathed to completely tear apart the Earth's surface and just leave all life on this planet obliterated the song big banger is literally what the title describes loudest song on the record I would wager maybe one of the loudest and lightning bolts discography with total blown out drums these trippy delayed lead vocals just swimming in this very compressed noisy mix these bass riffs that are just sliding the world they just sound like hundreds of giant motorcycles revving up it's just one of those lightning bolt tracks that grooves on this one insane a weird idea for a very long time thankfully we do get some tension release transitioning out of this at one point with some quickly strum chords mystical lead melodies it's like we've suddenly transitioned into a desert or something and we're just trying to survive a really intense sandstorm the song blow to the head the intro to this thing features some speedily rolling drums booming hits a bass easily some of the most exciting noise rock I've heard this year the triumphant bass leads on this track and vocals add an epic melody to an already gigantic sounding mix also the very messy and everything but the kitchen sink bridge on this track is gratifyingly disturbing thankfully the song air conditioned did grow on me at first when I heard it I did not like it at all I chalk a lot of that up to the sound quality of the first upload on Bandcamp being very bad thankfully the better fidelity version that I'm hearing on streaming services sounds great loving the very nutty lead vocals on this track the righteous chords the intense flurry of drums that pop in on the chorus in a lot of ways this track is a classic lightning bolt formula but performed with some riffs and some ideas and some writing that I haven't quite heard before it's it's familiar but refreshing I feel roughly the same way about Halloween 3 there are some ideas on the track that feel maybe a little deja vu for lightning bolts but the performance on that one is incredible as long as I'm talking about moments on this record that are a little predictable or underwhelming though Tom thump is easily one of the weakest links in the chain throughout the tracklist as it is quite obviously the most under written track on the entire record I would argue there are quite a few songs in the second half that are kind of so-so bouncy house is fantastic but then there's also Van Halen when the father behind the closing track on this thing which is over nine minutes long whoo and this is an amazing ending to this record it's more of a journey than it is a song lightning bolt has put out some pretty long and indulgent songs in their back catalogue over the years and this is easily one of my favorite closures they've ever done it starts out like a very raw chaotic Jam with both Brian's not really seeming like at first they have too much of a concrete idea as to where this is going they're just basically both making a lot of noise however the whole thing is gaining more and more and more momentum as it barrels forward into infinity adding on more and more of these unsettling dissonant layers eventually we reach a point where this incredible amount of momentum breaks and we're getting more coherent riffs more of the Brian's sounding like they're they're more in sync with each other but still the whole thing sounds incredibly unhinged even some noises I haven't quite heard on a lightning bolt record before it sounds like um occasionally there's some screaming blurting harmonica what it's actually ingeniously abrasive I'll say that again a fantastic finish to the album and its oddity as a track almost makes it indescribable overall I thought this thing was a great album I enjoyed it more than lightning bolts last record I think that it is pretty solid throughout a few lulls in the tracklist here and there but a really enjoyable admirable effort from lightning bolt I don't prefer this one to a lot of the group's classic stuff but still they are trying a lot of new things on this one and it's mostly panning out I'm feeling a strong seven to a light eight on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it hey everyone very thinnies sick tan oh here the Internet's most coughing music nerd not feeling well but still doing a review of the new Anna Franco electrico album little electric chicken heart this is the sophomore full-length album of Brazilian artist and a Franco electric oh who I am just becoming hip to now though it seems that she's been releasing music since last year under this name so I tried this record just like I do many albums that I see getting a bit of a mild buzz on the internet and I admit I didn't really know what to expect when I went into this one it's pretty short just a 30 minute album and the cover is just so simple and straightforward in fact it looks like an intentionally blurry shot out of a smartass French art film that's just in love with how unconventional it is but know this again is actually an album cover from a Brazilian rock artist and her band that creatively fuses together elements of chamber pop and Samba jazz and they do it with a style in a recording that sounds like it's straight out of the late 60s early 70s yes despite this album being very new anna Franco electric oh is actually mustered an authentically vintage sound one that gives me visions of hip art scenes where everyone's wearing tightly fitting black clothing and doing zany choreographed moves and smokey jazz clubs but don't let these similarities make you assume that this album is just boring or stuffy because this thing is actually a very fun playful colorful album with a lot of personality and smile inducing instrumentation to look at it as if it were that indie pop supergroup superorganism but instead what we have here is like a weird 70s Brazilian art school kid version of that the whole thing kicks off at the track so uh which I admit is a little repetitive but it's still incredibly lush groovy I love the jazzy and warm horns on this track the background vocals everything about it is so just bubbly the lazily strum guitars the plinky glockenspiel the whole thing just continues to ride this groove and gets progressively louder and louder and more fun the following track tones things down a little bit more it's a loose somewhat jazzy slow burner I'm not crazy about the more amateurish passages of this song or how long it takes to really get going compositionally there are a lot of things about this track I enjoy I just think the listless performance takes some wind out of the sails for a more subdued track I think the track chocolatte is a lot better there's a lot of grace shown in the performance despite how slow and spacious a lot of the instrumentation is also that transition into the second half is fantastic the tracks say no cinema seems to pick up the pace in the first leg though with more fusions of funky Samba rhythms as well as jazzy horns chords melodies as well as lots and lots and lots of cheeky group vocals the song almost feels flirty with how knowingly silly some of the musical components are but it's all executed so well even if it is a little funny you can't help but take it seriously the track temp sortez another great song in the tracklist here but one that makes the lo-fi recording quality of some of these tracks very apparent as some of the louder and more cacophonous spots on the song just get a little abrasive the vocals almost have a punk attitude that's a little reminiscent of groups on the more North American side of things like King Khan and the shrines how they had their own punked-out twist on the sounds of soul and funk also the drums in the background occasionally reach a point where they sound just like white noise pummeling away in the background still despite all that this track still features all of these characteristics of funk and rock and soul and pop music and samba coming together into this zany dance party with heads and arms waving in every direction the song Vendetta is a cool little sad guitar vignette that transitions into the next song on the project the song tour tour Doris which is mostly a very subdued watery guitar ballad a few old-school horn lines here and there it's a somewhat sleepy but cute track loving a lot more of the following deba terra cotta menos the absolutely dejected intro on this track is great it's clunky it's awkward reminds me of tracks off of like Iggy Pop's the idiot with how alien it sounds at least in comparison with other tracks off of this project but then the band explodes occasionally into these more aggressive passages that really lets loose the tension that they were building up on these weird-ass versus the girthy horns the noisy drums those background vocals again during these passages are amazing the song caspo is a pretty sweet send-off for the entire record feels like the credits rolling on a weird foreign film that i just watched a lot of groups singing a lot of jazzy horn embellishments a sweet chord set - it all ends in an endearing ly noisy fashion overall this thing I'm loving it but I'm left wanting more but still loving it this is easily one of the most fun records I've heard this year and it's great that this Brazilian artist was able to come through with this old-school yet refreshing and exciting sound hopefully more people pay attention to this band and the Brazilian music scene as well as a result of this project not to say every other album an artist from there sounds like this they don't but Ana Franco Electrico could certainly be the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the fantastic stuff going on down in Brazil right now I'm feeling a light too decent eight on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe please don't cry if the bail is well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel kathan e Fantan o hi everyone needs a nice leap tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new big thief album two hands two of them this is the newest full-length LP from buzzing in defaulters big thief fronted by currently one of the most distinct singers in the genre right now Adrian linker big thief has been making quite a bit of headway over the past few years the band's mix of intricate but enchanting folk instrumentation and odd but expressive lead vocals have not only earned them a 4ad record contract but also leagues of diehard fans ready to go to the mat for them and while their record you FoF earlier this year was definitely a breakout moment for them despite the wide praise amongst fans and many publications I just could not bring myself to get into it as much I just did not see what was so profound about it meanwhile while I don't love the band's 2017 record capacity at least that album was a bit more focused consistent seemed like it had an identity meanwhile you FoF in comparison is so the scattershot unsure of its direction and occasionally despite the unique characteristics of big thief's music drowning in its influences just not not that strong of a personality to it so with this wave of success that big thief is writing the band is doing something that is rare for a group in indie folk especially one that is up-and-coming and that is drop two albums within five months of each other where all these tracks written in workshop and recorded within that time period I don't know but either way it's a lot of music to be dropping in such a short amount of time big picture I suppose it does make sense as big thief is just as subjected to the over saturation of the music industry as any rapper making three mixtapes a year is I went into this record worried though that there would be no reason to even listen to it because within this span of time how would big thief come through with a distinct sound instead of songs that actually feels different from you FoF and hopefully more appealing to me than you FoF but the band actually did it and not by indulging in a bunch of experiments and abstractions know this record is very much about big thief taking it back to basics instrumentally I would say it's kind of the spiritual successor to capacity as in the tracklist here the banned folds one tuneful expressive subtly weird folk tune on top of another sure the production is not as slick as it was on UFO f there are not as many bells and whistles but there's really nothing to distract from the focus of just delivering some quality straightforward solid songwriting here which when you're talking about a genre is simple and is rustic generally as folk music can't be a bad thing now maybe this is to a point where some of the instrumental pallets here are a bit bland like on the very subdued those girls or on these somewhat breezy replaced or maybe a song such as the intro comes off a little brief under written still though there's a very nice handful of highlights on this thing most of the tracks on this record are incredibly enjoyable for one the track forgotten highs one of the most solid and/or playable songs and spanned has ever put out I love the rich acoustic chords on this track I love how nimble and dynamic linkers vocals are she's just ice dancing on this instrumental easily one of her best performances on the entire record and the song has this lovely almost romantic intoxicating quality to it just gets me swaying immediately and I'm so taken with the lyrics on this one too which range from being incredibly surreal but beautiful forgotten eyes are the ones which we lose forgotten hands are the ones which we choose then we get spots on the same track that are wonderfully relatable like everybody needs a home and deserves protection hmm I also love the track two hands with these speedy quickly played guitar arpeggios and the somewhat metallic and rickety percussion in the background it hits a good pace all this sets a very simple and a raw foundation for linkers slightly low five vocal performance here it's a wonderfully organic in the moment recording that just feels so intimate also that melodic transition into the chorus the it's just so warm and inviting and welcoming it feels familiar but also refreshing and new leggers voice reminds me of points of like a violin we also have the track not which is a grim piece of full crock with lots of distorted extended guitar solos it reaches this urgent darkness that reminds me of like an old classic Neil Young song or two and wolf despite being one of the quietest tracks here is easily one of the most compelling and worthwhile the hypnotic acoustic finger-picking is tight as hell the rustic lead melodies as well as some of linkers most poetic writing on the entire project the sense of longing on this track is so thick you could cut it with a knife stab it with a fork scoop it with a spoon I don't have an incredible amount of praise for this record past this point but it is a very good in solid set of tracks I enjoyed it certainly much more than big thief's last record I may be in the minority on that but it is what it is I would love to hear the band in the future be able to build on this sound without losing sight of these characteristics that make them what they are and even though there are a handful of tracks here that I wish were more fleshed out or a bit bolder I still find this to be a very solid and enjoyable indie folk record a don't miss if you're a die-hard for the genre I'm feeling a light too decent seven on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review channel Anthony Fantana big thief's forever

hi everyone gloom Denis doom tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new richard dawson album 2020 this is the latest full-length LP from english singer and songwriter richard dawson who in my opinion has been one of indie Fulks best kept secrets for the past decade or so over the years dawson has amassed a strange but versatile discography which piqued my interest with the release of his album peasant a few years ago a project that featured basically an hour these neo medieval folk songs with bold but blemished acoustic guitars basically archaic noise Foulke and through some very animated vocal performances Dawson would tell these stories inspired by the days of yore mentioning cauldrons and kingdoms and soldiers while also singing about the dark and savage side of this era to the abject poverty selling children for grain Richards latest project here is a change of pace though of course the antiquated but updated English folk isms that have inspired much of Dawsons discography also carry over onto 2020 but there's a lot more electric instrumentation here there are some weird synths and vocal effects occasionally drums too this album is very much a product of our modern era not just in its sound but in its lyrics too I mean the title of this thing is 2020 it's very obviously looking forward to the very near future with one song after another reading like a slightly dystopian take on our late stage capitalists present there are tracks on this thing referencing our current day problems with modern technology our environment the political landscape also workers toiling away in an Amazon Fulfillment Center and even though this project is different the matically and sonically from Richard Dawson's previous peasant there are some interesting ways in which these records parallel in their runtime in the melody writing both albums actually feature a song titled no one a short little interlude track on the second to last song of the record and even though both these albums are from different time periods narrative Lee they both feature stories with protagonists that are essentially caught in or struggling against the prevailing problems of the society they were born into so in a way it's safe to say that peasant in 2020 our sister albums or connected or one is the sequel to the other and in my opinion 2020 is every bit as ingenious and creative as its predecessor though maybe Dawson's lyrics on this one are bit more cutting because he is a product of the era that he's critiquing and while I really do love the ideas that Dawson is putting forward on this album the instrumentals in my opinion are just as intriguing the explosive tracks civil-servant is an amazing kick-off to this project at the very start with these grunting grinding off-kilter riffs paper bran that mechanical repetition I feel like I'm being ground into the gears of a failing society or chased down by a madman with a knife after this we quickly transition into these tense narrative verses the day for our protagonist begins very mundane getting up morning pouring some cereal and being subjected to another day at a job that you despise we get an epic triumphant chorus on this one with some odd falsetto vocals some of the medieval elements of peasant really come back during moments like this our protagonist goes into these inner thoughts later into the track about wanting to beat a co-worker's head in basically to a bloody pulp wanting to call in sick and struggling with processing the traumas of the people that this person has to deal with which all sounds little self-centered yes but Dawson's characterization of people in these civil servant positions isn't too much different than what is often reported by people who are social workers in the u.s. working crazy hours dealing with a lack of resources being worked to the point where you're jaded and you don't care about your job anymore just take it as the Avant noise full UK version of take this job and shove it Dawson reels it back in a little bit with the much less noisy the Queen's head which is a sobering tale about an English town flooded which when researching I saw is not too uncommon of an occurrence in the UK with notable and recent floods happening in oh seven oh eight oh nine twelve and fifteen I love the plucky weird folky instrumentation on this track the grand rush of synths and vocals on the hook but most interesting on this track are the vivid descriptions of people dealing with this ordeal whether it be the vape shop guy ferrying his chocolate labs on a leaky kayak or a local butcher handing out food while loudly proclaiming the lack of flood defences is because of foreigners coming over and making use of public services and of course we have the genius mantra on this track of how little we are basically depicting humanity as being helpless in the face of the wrath of nature which they are stirring through the destruction of the environment then Dawson dishes out two of the catchiest song is on the entire record with two halves and jogging the come on come on refrains on the former are just too good I also love the galloping groove on the latter two and while it seems like Dawson is singing from the standpoint of other people on this record much of the time his descriptions of dealing with anxiety on this particular cut just seemed too detailed to not come from a personal place next we have the track heart emoji which sees the skipping muted guitar lines repeating along with these sporadic synth embellishments that are very gentle essentially it's a song about finding out that your partner is cheating by seeing some texts on their phone the whole thing comes to a bloody end that I won't totally spoil but I think that Dawson's character comes to the conclusion that some infidelity is going on pretty fast and maybe the ending would have been more interesting a little less absurd if the protagonist had realized he had come to a false assumption or something the song black triangle has one of the loudest and weirdest intros of any track on here it feels like a warp take on some classic arena rock song with grimy guitars and these fast little synth chords do it's like listening to the who's who are you but nightmare version the whole thing quickly transitions into these fast angular post-punk guitars and drums black MIDI fans take notice so you have this long winding multi-phase song structure these hard grieving verses and all this is attached to a story about a guy who had a run-in with a UFO then he becomes obsessed with UFOs to the point where he has a website and a YouTube channel where he tracks sightings his obsession seems to be destroying his marriage - it's a hilarious and enthralling song about getting caught up in a very weird thing but there you have it also the zany vocal harmonies during the last climax of the song are fantastic it's like in listening to a sci-fi folk Punk epic then we have fulfillment center which is a 10 minute long track and maybe has way more for thought put into it than any song about working in a fulfillment center should but I think Dawson does a great job of depicting the daily health at people who are caught in these types of jobs have to face the repetition all the products having to be shipped at such a fast pace people falling asleep on the job or disgruntled workers being escorted off the premises also having your movements and your work be timed and peeing into a bottle because you can't go to the bathroom Dawson also depicts this work as being an endless cycle with his protagonist saying that there is nothing left of them by the time they go home before they have to just go to sleep and wake up again to just start all over freshers ball is a decent low key moment in the tracklist here it's a so-so song about feeling lonely and missing someone while also finding solace in some little things and some silver linings of these clouds and the closer dead dog in an alleyway is a really climactic end of this record the grim imagery of the dead dog and having trouble finding a place to sleep and rest juxtaposed against the cold and callous never-ending movements of the city which Dawson depicts as a labyrinth of neon which is one of many moments of poetic genius across this project I'm really loving this one I'm living the shit out of this one what a challenging smart witty fun and unsettling contribution to the full catalog I'm also loving the personal and story centric songwriting throughout many of these tracks - which in a way reminds me a little bit of mark kozilek Sun Kil moon but obviously a lot of the storytelling here is much more dystopian and the instrumentals are coming from a totally different planet then there's also the case of Dawson singing which is just so expressive I think that Dawson's voice - many newcomers might sound a little homely but it certainly fits there snugly in these very sour and oddly catchy instrumentals if you're looking for a more pleasant and breezy and eful experience you might want to avoid this one maybe but personally I'm loving how unique and daring this project is I think that maybe it would be great if all of the themes and the stories tied together and in some way conceptually by the end of the whole thing they don't it's really just a collection of tracks but there's a great amount of focus amongst all of those songs and and a hell of a lot of great playing creative writing very memorable lyrics and stories and even though this thing is so dense it is so replayable at least for me anyway I'm feeling a light too decent 9:00 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana richard Dawson forever

uh hey everyone there theny there tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds album Ghost teen this is the newest record from legendary singer and songwriter Nick Cave and his band the Bad Seeds who have spent this decade sounding a lot more mellow than bad with records like push the sky away as well as skeleton tree and now ghosting all three of these albums essentially accounting for some of the most ambient moody and low-key records in the entire Nick Cave discography and for me that's meant a lot of highs and a lot of lows while I wasn't crazy about push the sky away I did love the profoundly dark and mournful tone of skeleton tree and ghost teen is essentially the third and final installment in this very melancholic trilogy now of course I can't say that I was surprised to hear that ghost teen was equally as low-key as its predecessors especially since this album comes well after the sudden passing of Nick Cave son and Nick spends quite a bit of time meditating on exactly that I mean he is essentially the ghost teen the album is titled after if anything is surprising about this album though it is the very lush and flowery cover depicting this idyllic green garden with flamingos and a horse and all these flowers it's beautiful its inviting it looks like something that would be on the cover of a book of fables and Nick uses exactly that iconography in his lyrics to explore his grief whether he's referencing kings and queens on the opening spinning song or on this collection of lyrics from the title track the three bears watched the TV they aged a lifetime oh Lord mama bear holds the remote papa bear he just floats and baby bear has gone to the moon in a boat these are not necessarily themes and aesthetics that I typically muscles it with a Nick Cave album that's not necessarily a bad thing either I think a lot of the writing on this thing is a welcome change of pace for Nick but I do think there are some elements of the music of the instrumentation that doesn't fully line up in fact ghost teen is like listening to two albums within one album and I don't just mean by virtue of this thing being pretty much a double or a two part album with a lot of these short moody vignettes kicking off the first portion and then we get these longer monstrous ten minute plus cuts in the second half no there's also the case of the instrumental tone the instrumental pallets of this project switching up and not I guess cohesively flowing in a way I care for that much it's either I'm listening to Nick Cave totally broken up over these ornately arranged beautiful rich organic instrumentals with an orchestral edge they're very weepy and occasionally cinematic so we have that where we're getting these long stretches of time where Nick is crooning over these minimal beds of synthesizers now sometimes these Styles overlap and pretty creatively I might add like on the track galleon ship which transitions from these droning very simple synth leads to this gorgeous rush of strings that is is really one of the prettiest moments on the entire project but not every synth bass track here meets that same glorious finish nor is every synth backed song on this record topped with the same quality poetry I'm also left wondering who exactly programmed these synthesizers because the sounds they're generating are not really all that great or immersive or flavorful much of the time the synths on this thing sound very rudimentary clunky awkward tinny generic I would say they ruin the moods of these tracks more than they enhance them most of the time and as long as we're talking about the sound of ghost teen this record is way too compressed for an album that is this quiet the whole thing just feels artificially loud and it's especially distracting considering how gentle the performances come off plus there's at least a few tracks here mostly ghost teen speaks as well as Leviathan where I find the compositions to be very banal and repetitive I get that this record is mostly about just kind of creating an instrumental vibe for Nick to just do his thing vocally and lyrically on top of again these tracks are very much vignettes motifs meditations extended quite a bit though I like a good record you can really marinate in the issue is I just don't really want to marinate in the sounds of the Nick and his band or generating here I just don't find the generic synth and occasionally sterile strains to be all that intriguing now look this is not the case for every track and if there is a major saving grace to pretty much every song here it is Nick's poetry it is Nick's singing these characteristics are really what make the sadness the potent sadness of this record translate so clearly especially on the opener especially on the whimpering eerie vocals and the second half of Hollywood especially as on the track waiting for you Nick's voice cracks like really hard as he is singing waiting for you waiting for you waiting for you making it easily one of the most powerful vocal performances of the year just from an emotional standpoint also on this project there are plenty of moments where Nick's words reach poetic genius like on the track Sun forest which features all of this very surreal and unsettling imagery of children climbing up and up and up it's profoundly chilling in one of the few moments on this record where Nick's voice hits that very grim Stern tone that he's known for the title track which works in multiple phases has this amazing build of strings around the midpoint which is enhanced with all these pianos and group vocalists it's grand it's gorgeous it's a high point on the album so there are certainly things I appreciate about this record and I think at the end of the day I came out enjoying most of it I just don't perceive it to be as one of Nick's best though is it one of my favorite sounding Nick Cave albums not really do I think it's one of his best composed do I think it's the most focused on the concept at hand not necessarily but from the standpoint of the vocals the lyrics as well as some of the narratives coming out of this thing it's easily one of Nick caves best so if you're someone who's more attracted to those elements of music and songwriting I highly recommend this record so it's certainly likable I see why people are more into it than I am and regardless of whether or not this is one of my favorites of Nick caves I am glad that he put out this record and was bold enough to share the turmoil he's been going through so earnestly feeling a decent too strong seven on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Nick Cave forever

ooh hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Sturgill Simpson album sound and fury this is the newest album from country renegade Sturgill Simpson it comes several years after his fantastic and widely acclaimed a sailor's guide to earth a great contribution to the modern country catalog fusing the genre with elements of rock elements of soul with some very grand and vast production occasionally some progressive compositional transitions Simpson is essentially a country artist who has the potential to do things in the genre that are left field that are outside of the norm that are ground breaking while simultaneously appealing to the core audience of that genre which is rare and because of that I have very much been looking forward to whatever his next record is going to be so here we have it sound and fury several years later but it comes after a turbulent series of events first we have Simpsons 2017 Grammy win for a country album of the year then a sinus infection so bad it required surgery leading to a lengthy recovery process that I'm reading Simpson mostly spent hi out of his mind he spent much of this downtime listening to old favorites outside of the country genre so eventually when he reconvened with the band they were ready to do even more unlikely fusions with the style sound and fury was also recorded in two weeks and comes along with a companion film on Netflix that Simpson wrote and produced along with the founder of a Tokyo animation studio kamikaze Doga the whole thing is about a post-apocalyptic Samurai so it kind of goes without saying that Simpson is coming from a somewhat weird place on this one and sure at its core it doesn't sound like Simpson has changed his songwriting style too much many of these tracks as out there as they can be do have a distinct country twang to them but Simpson and his band are dressing these country tunes in tons of compression tons of overdrive hardrock guitars disco rhythms vintage semi futuristic synthesizers all you have to do is hear a few seconds of the sci-fi synth leads and the chunky rhythms and the mind-numbing to know guitar leads on best clockmaker on Mars to hear that we are not in Kansas anymore look I'm not going to beat around the bush on this one these tracks are pretty experimental for Simpson any major relevant country artist working today really some of these experiments sound fantastic and others go so awry they make for Simpsons worst material to date for one I love the tracks sing-along which was great as a teaser even better as a poor song on the record fat drums on this track are fantastic the funky gurgly keyboard licks the whaling slide guitars too it's got a great groove I love Simpsons totally buzzing fuzz doubt lead vocal on this one the song sounds like an old friend but also like an alien from another planet the screaming synth leads on the bridge of this cut are nice - it's like I'm listening to dystopian cyber country I also love the track good look which is backed with these very fast peppy groovy disco beats that bassline that hip shaking beat those bright fluttery layers of strings on the track they all sound like something straight out of 1975 and the way the whole instrumental transitions into this loud laser synth breakdown is crazy when the instrumental clears on the verse a very solid tune is revealed as well as some smart and snappy lyrics about the end of the world Fame copyrights the song Ronan isn't the bad instrumental kickoff to this thing even though I think it does drag on a bit too long it's a little too impressed with its own lumbering rhythms and somewhat bland guitar passages remember to breathe there's also a track that I think contributes to the first leg of this album being incredibly solid however once you hit the midpoint of this thing I think the quality begins to take a nosedive for one I cannot stand make art not friends it takes way too long to get started and when it eventually gets there it's this slow lumbering awkward patience testing song you couldn't have up to the tempo on this one a little bit just just a smidge at this pace this track sounds like a bad Gary Numan song or at least like the band is is trying to perform in quicksand already voiced my annoyances with best clock maker on Mars those two note guitar riffs are awful all said and done is a very sweet mellow melodic oasis in the second leg of this record but it's still not a highlight for me meanwhile the production on Last Man Standing is trash it just sounds like a really bad live recording with the guitars blaring to the point where they're smothering everything the drums sound like they're being played at a distance the vocals are muffled and and just really unintelligible much of the time so even if the song at the core of this one is one of the bettors of this entire project you you wouldn't really be able to tell from just how not good it sounds some of the new wave elements that were very lightly referenced earlier on the record come back on mercury in retrograde where it sounds like we have some nice punchy drums some lightly phased and gently strum guitars it's plucky it's pretty sounds a little intergalactic when you get that wonderful rush of instrumentation on the chorus there are some parts of it that remind me of the cars then we have the fastest horse in town the longest track on the entire record and it is so goddamn loud especially the guitars it just gets more and more distorted the whole thing is like an asteroid burning up in Earth's atmosphere look there are some elements of this album that I admire that I think are risky that I think are very cool and there are others that again I don't think compliment Simpson all that much I don't think go over that well I think frankly sound awful I like that Simpson and his band really let loose on this one but a lot of terrible ideas and sounds go completely unchecked and there are really enough of them to make this record a very spotty inconsistent listen I'm feeling a decent two strong five on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video for you to check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana sound and fury forever

haha hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new Billy woods record terror management this is a record from one of the most mysterious rappers operating right now Billy woods he's from the east coast at least I think he is who really knows where Billy woods is from he's like a shadow one that's being cast by a street light or the full moon he's there and he's also not Billy woods is the dark web he's the feeling of knowing that a pair of eyes are watching you and he's pretty prolific too between his solo works as well as the increasingly popular duo he formed with a lucid Armand Hammer he's put out like nine projects over the past seven years many of them account for some of my favorite hip-hop records of the decade race music paraffin history will absolve me known unknowns his recent project with Kenny Siegel has been one of his most widely celebrated yet turning a lot of new Billy listeners into hardcore fans and that thing just dropped this past March now again for new Billy listeners I could see why that project would be a bit of a revelation Billy's delivery is unique and one-of-a-kind it's a mix of rapping shouting narration the tone of his lyrics are a mix of grim realities and depressing social commentaries loaded with wit dark humor and presented in a way where it's a little esoteric so it's not coming off to direct or preachy case in point the track Trivial Pursuit off of his new project over here where he's going on about a white person recognizing him by his voice if you don't know Billy woods likes to keep his face pretty obscured so Billy being recognized by his voice and then saying white people are born cops one more line that stood out shorty Cantino book is what I told Tana hussy coats and there's so much truth at one bar when you unpack it with it obviously being a nod to poverty going hungry and then tying that into the work of writer and political commentator Tana Haji Coates who does have some smart observations about the current political landscape but in his own way Billy acknowledges that his observations as well as his solutions to modern problems come from a place of privilege as it's really difficult to fuel a revolution on starvation wages the messages being reinforced later about all of the lies Billy woods learned in Community College or not being able to read a book if he tried and the way all this compounds into a commentary on Western education its miss truths but also its ineffectiveness for those who are born into poverty with serious material needs so this is often how Woods tracks work he throws raw ideas and snippets and observations out there that are obviously connected in some way but you sort of have to fill in the blanks to see what he's getting at and realize all of the answers are overlapping like a crossword puzzle and being able to make these connections often requires the listeners to have a framework of American history and so much more as they're still tracks from woods back catalogue that I love but I'm still decoding to this day so going into this new one I was basically just hoping for something new refreshing maybe even thematic creatively the dude really seems to be on a streak and personally I think he's been putting out great stuff all along and it's just amazing to see that that now finally people are beginning to realize it I gotta say though this new one I'm not finding it to be as gratifying as many abilities a recent works a lot of the instrumentals here are textured but very repetitive dusty a little humdrum as brooding and dark as some of the instrumentals are on Marlow and myth and blood thinner the loops just get very stale very fast it really means something on this project when Billy spits a bar like I wish I could have waited inside that moment forever like a beat loop occasionally it does feel that way in a way this record does remind me of Armand hammers second project Rome as that's easily the most under produced project Billy has released with a lucid so far and here Billy is sounding similarly loose rough around the edges a little unfocused a direction that I think complements some artists very well and given Billy's very grimy pedigree I can't deny that it does compliment him to some extent but I still think multiple core tracks from this project leave a lot to be desired whether it be the very was II and nearly comatose cornstarch which is wrapped in this very lazy slow-mo style it's like Billy's is on the verge of falling asleep it's a cool experiment but the lack of direction and structure prevents it from having much in the way of any impact quite a few underwhelming cuts on here and even when Billy manages to do something more in-your-face often the energy feels misdirected numerous tracks on this thing are also surrounded with these much shorter cuts that just feel very fleeting they don't really inspire much outside of a spare quotable or two that was then myth dog days and these songs are not to be confused with the multiple wrapped vignettes off of Billy's very ambitious 2015 record today I wrote nothing an album that was essentially a very creative exercise and brevity there are also a few other tracks on here that aren't quite as short but maybe toward the end or even in the middle transition into a very lengthy vocal snippet maybe from a movie or a series I'm not familiar with the source material and this is certainly not the first time Billy has worked stuff like this into his records and I most likely would have enjoyed these bits more had the songs been hardy ER but these spots often feel unnecessary distracting like filler and usually communicate more than the music preceding them does which brings me to some of the guests on this thing especially fielded who appears on this project more than anyone else while I do enjoy her singing when it pops up it certainly makes this entire project a lot less monotonous often her appearances just allow Billy to extend an otherwise underwritten track either taking up the whole first leg or second leg of a track before it just fades to black the closer on this thing is mostly inconsequential to I just feel like I have so many complaints about this one and maybe that's because I have such a high opinion of Billy's work up until this point but there are cuts on this thing I like quite a bit Western education is forbidden that I was talking about earlier the song gas leak whose instrumental is fantastic one of the best on the entire record with these very raw and resonant drums eventually leading into these shots of industrial noise rhymes that dart back and forth like a man going through a manic monologue in his head the beats which in the middle of the track is fantastic I also love the insane psychedelic on low five birds on one of Billy's best lyrical and vocal performances on the entire project all the guest verses here from maka me pink Sifu as well as acai solo certainly improves long grass as well as wind Hoek and Fonua new which I'm not sure I'm pronouncing correctly but still easily the most eerie song in the entire project billy's refrains on this track compiled with the either effects or overdubs on his voice sound like a nightmare also the plucky strings on the beats which in the second leg of the track the way Billy's vocals just intensify as he's delivering some of the best lyricism on the entire record so yeah there are certainly highlights here and there's nothing honestly on the record I thought was terrible incredibly disappointing I was just left wanting more from most of it and still at the end of the day this is a billy woods album by that fact alone you are going to walk into this record with a certain level of talent and style and flair that you're not going to get in many other places so even in it's as is somewhat dodgy current state there are still some cool beats there's still a lot of details there are still nooks and crannies just a lot of it isn't fleshed out very far I'm feeling eight decent too strong six on this one transition have you given this one listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should hire you next hit the like if you like please subscribe but and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Billy woods terror management forever

hi everyone vibe the new check tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Danny Brown album you know what I'm saying Michigan rapper Danny Brown who has been one of the grime iasts to ever do it and he's back with a new album what can be said about Danny Brown other than that he is the definition of ahead of the curve raised in a hip hop landscape he was just too unorthodox for as his career didn't really begin to take off until he hit the age of 30 with his breakout mixtape of the same title in 2011 but when Danny did eventually start to turn heads his unique qualities became a draw his druggie raunchy excessive lyrics his party anthems that were simultaneously a dark cry for help and all of it delivered in this wild yell pee inflection that really sounded like nothing else at the time though in retrospect it's really easy to draw stylistic comparisons to pioneers like the wu-tang's ODB as well as Cypress Hills be real now while this is not something I discuss too often in reviews but another draw - Danny was definitely his look the side shave his colorful clothing and of course his missing front tooth it's worth it to bring up though because since then since the earlier leg of this decade it seems like Danny has cleaned up and matured quite a bit even going as far as to fill that legendary gap it's like he's transitioned from being the biggest party animal on the planet to everybody's cool uncle and I've been wondering what this could mean for future releases from Danny essentially giving up that reckless look and lifestyle that fuelled his most popular material especially after his last record 2016 atrocity exhibition took such a dark turn it's a record I named my album of the year that year Danny's performances and lyrics and instrumental choices on this one are so extreme I doubt he'll ever top this record not that I need him to ultimately all I want Danny to do is evolve so where do you go after such a dark and challenging statement well with you know what I'm saying it sounds like Danny is pretty much simplifying things streamlining reeling things in on a lot of fronts for one this is his shortest project in a long long time would have to go back to some of his earliest mixtapes to hear something shorter 11 songs 34 minutes there also doesn't seem to be a concept or a major theme pulling all of these tracks together either and Danny still has unique taste for beats but there's nothing on here that's as wild or bombastic as like a blunt after blunt or ain't it funny in fact multiple tracks and instrumentals here feel like a bit of a stylistic throwback it feels like a slightly subversive update on a lot of classic rap formulas as a matter of fact none other than A Tribe Called Quest's q-tip executive produced this thing and it shows in its old-school ear so given these potpourri and somewhat scattered characteristics of this record the enjoy ability of it really boils down to whether or not each one of these tracks is great individually or if it's somehow it gets tiresome before the record is over I can tell you that last one is not really an issue I am actually left wanting more by the time this thing is finished and most of the tracks Danny delivers here are actually pretty good there are some underwhelming spots though like the intro change-up which in my opinion is a slightly boring tone setter it's almost like Danny is not trying to build up expectations too much for this thing we have an atmospheric instrumental not a whole lot of groove a clunkier version of a very familiar flow understated delivery at least for Danny anyway I like the sentiment of the song this idea of Danny not looking back going forward being unwilling to change in a way that would cheapen his art or himself it's just a somewhat bland kick off we also have the title track here whose instrumental sounds more fitting for that of a young alternative R&B singer just swimming in a lot of space and atmosphere the messaging gets a little tedious too with Danny relaying a piece of advice or a life observation and following that up with know what I'm saying it's certainly not the worst thing I've ever heard Danny put out but it's so OneNote the biggest breath of fresh air on the track is actually the featured artist or bong Junior who brings these deep smoky vocals of this track really pops out I love his voice on belly of the beast - I have complaints about that track too though Danny's writing on this track is some of the funniest and wittiest on the entire record I'm anemic with the ink you a Stevie Wonder blink I take a piss in the same sink you wash dishes with you're illiterate you're Bisquick soft I put the biscuit then you dip like cocktail sauce I use so many shrimp I got iodine poison hose on my dick because I look like Roy Orbison that is certainly some classic Danny Brown if I've ever heard some but I just do not get this barely there whooshing instrumental that doesn't really support Danny or his guests on the track it just feels like just just a very weak foundation thankfully the rest of what's here is pretty high-grade the track three tiers featuring run the jewels also has production from JPEG mafia totally bangs even if the rtj feature is pretty standard for them at this point I love the track theme song on which there is a mystical and strange instrumental Danny delivers these brutally frank bars he's kind of flexing his vet status on this track I never thought I would see the day where Danny transitions from partying weirdo who's widely misunderstood to having enough clout to look down on younger rappers as if they're uniquely lost or clueless but here we are even going as far as to say you need to learn some respect and I've done more for the game than you it doesn't leave the best taste in my mouth but I guess Danny has earned the right at this point he could have easily lost it all like many other rappers who popped off around the same time he did but instead he's still going relatively strong after well over a decade in the industry and holding on to his artistic integrity the whole time I wasn't crazy about dirty laundry when I first heard it it has these weird squeaky synths laced into the instrumental and Danny's flow read to me more like spoken word at some points with how I guess mid-paced it is and how much space there is in between many bars but it's grown on me with more lessons mostly because the instrumental is so odd and I'm loving the concept lyrically that Danny has pulled through on this track talking about dirty secrets and experiences from his past working in all these references to laundry dirtiness soap cleaning with the whole narrative tying back up at a laundromat on the finish easily one of Danny's most well formulated tracks so far we also have the killer savage nomads which goes harder than any other cut here with those droning bass hits those sparkling guitar lead samples that classic lo-fi hip-hop beat the quotables on this track are on fire whether Danny's saying something simple like same shit different porta potti or it's quite simple I'm mental all over instrumental detrimental to hit lyrics is quintessential it's a good mix of flash and brutality on the song best life we hear kind of a hopeful forward-looking Danny which is rare it's like he's embracing his new life path over a rich soulful instrumental that is very feel-good kind of blissful I love the tight string samples on this track how well they complement Danny's lyrics about moving forward progressing getting away from your dark past and things that used to stress you out also got a compliment the tight-end busy Negro spiritual which features some great production and and playing from Flying Lotus and Thundercat the drumbeats are intricate they are shifting Thundercats bases just wild angular all over the place it provides a very strange intense foundation for Danny's almost manic rapping we also have JPEG mafia on the hook here sadi didn't have a full verse to add to this track but his very expressive raspy tone on this cut which which is almost wheezy I guess I'll say wheezy was kind of a surprise the man has so many inflections and in deliveries he's easily one of the most dynamic artists out there and he killed the hook I also love Danny's writing style and delivery on this track it's almost like I'm listening to a more insane version of hybrid era Danny it's like he's finally channeling the dark energy is that surround him that his music embodies a lot of the time and focusing them in a creative way danny is also complemented by blood orange on the following track shine which emotionally is a mix of hope and tragedy danny is reveling in the success in the shine that he has built up but he's also feeling paranoid and vulnerable like his career can be ripped away from him at any moment by I don't know what but still even as he's moving forward and doing better these dark thoughts still paint the back of his mind now if this album were more thematic or conceptual I would love a closer that kind of ties things up and and tells us exactly what this record is about but we don't really get that instead we get the track combat which is still a great track you know it's it's one of the punchy ER songs here one of the slicker songs here so it doesn't make for a bad finish it features production from q-tip vocals from q-tip also consequences on here of all people that's awesome that he came through and the song is great I mean instrumentally it feels like a classic tribe anthem with these fluttery horn samples and great somewhat chunky lo-fi rhythms vocally Danny tones it down a little but not as aggressive not as in-your-face not as nasal lower register and in this gear over this instrumental Danny actually sounds like the rap veteran that he truly is skilled expressive lyrical clever dealing in themes of trauma violence and survival not too much more for me to say about the album broadly I mean it's just a really great collection of tracks a few duds here and there but that's it the vibe is definitely more casual than that of Danny's other core projects but it also speaks to his talent and his artistry for him to drop a project of this caliber without having to overthink it I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it but would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is a another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Danny Brown you know what I'm saying forever
