hi everyone earth any hurt a no here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new weather day album come in this is the new semi breakout album from Swedish music project weather day and I say breakout because this record has stirred quite the commotion in the underground music community mostly within the realms of lo-fi and bedroom pop and from what I can tell the buzz is not due to some celebrity endorsement or a major label deal it seems pretty organic with many fans hailing this album as an artistic feat for DIY whatever Sputnik the mastermind of weather day is doing it's really striking a chord they're not working with an unfamiliar mix of genres though there is certainly some indie rock going into this record some noise pop some emo occasionally all of this is enhanced with some great background vocals pianos some samples or even electronics and the whole recording is as low Phi as a motherfucker if you're the kind of person who might avoid a Neutral Milk Hotel album or a microphones or a Mount Erie album because there are too many noisy lo-fi bits within it you are not going to have a fun time with this one think of taking the incredibly low fidelity of a waves album in early waves album and then trying to apply to that the instrumental ambition of an old Sufjan Stevens record and while that's not a perfect comparison it's close in some respects this album is more abrasive and harsh than a classic Scandinavian black metal album I mean those squeaking wailing lead melodies that top the choruses of the track cut lips are absolutely ear piercing not just ear piercing but ear stabbing they're most likely giving someone tinnitus right now who's listening to this thing way too loud I can't say Sputnik isn't doing a lot with a little on this record though they're certainly very creative with how they choose to operate within the very limited fidelity of sound that they work with in the performances on this thing aren't bad either sure they are pretty sloppy but still they are delivered with a lot of heart a lot of energy certainly all the chaos of this record is complemented with the explosive energy it presents case in point the song older than or easily some of the most fun throttling rock music I've heard this year between the crunchy rhythm guitars and sparkling arpeggios the distorted and sandpaper rough drums on this track to adding all of this together I think Sputnik shows more guts than most major label rock releases dropping this year and again that is despite the low fire recording that is despite all the instrumentation sounding so claustrophobic it's like it's been squeezed into a drainpipe and I'm not exactly sure what's causing that obviously it's intentional but is it because everything was recorded too loudly was it all done in post I'm not sure either way the whole thing sounds like if you were sitting comfortably in your living room on the couch but every other piece of furniture around you was on fire in that respect come in isn't too different from the early works of let's say car seat headrest and even though I think most of the similarities between weather day and car C headrest end with their low fidelity recordings I have no doubt this album is thriving because of the demand that projects like twin fantasy as well as teens of denial have created not just for rock music that's low Phi but low Phi rock music that's also thematic as well as ambitious and conceptual in some ways come in as like low Phi's answer to the rock opera as this record features 10-minute songs melodic reprises as well as tragic lyrics car seat headrest isn't the only comparison I'd like to make in this review though because I'm seeing other artistic parallels with the likes of early Conor Oberst whether that be super super super early bright eyes or commander Venus some 90s emo maybe even some more melodic cuts from the hsker d discography and most certainly Phil elrom everything Phil elrom I would say their points on this thing that are blatant Phil elrom worship like on the final moments of sleep while doing your best the droning basins singing on that track and certainly there are some piano passages that have that really sharp ringing pain to them that I remember so vividly from records like the glow part 2 so truthfully some of the material on this project if you are familiar with the worlds of lo-fi and indie singer-songwriter music can feel a little derivative or even kind of bland like on the track water dreamer this the first leg of which I think could have used a little something extra it's not bad but it does feel like the album is beginning to paint itself into a corner the instrumental switch in the second leg of this track drags on a little bit - then there's also the very same Ian's underwhelming first leg of the track porcelain hands the closer here I do love that the main theme melody of this record that pops up also on the intro comes back for a grand finale but the washed out vocals and guitars that have little to no flavor or rather have lost their flavor by this point on the project aren't doing any favors for this thing being the closing track however the majority of songs on this record if you can get past the lo-fi production or even enjoy and appreciate what Sputnik does with it then and only then I think you'll find come in to be pretty catchy anthemic ambitious and emotionally compelling the first two tracks on this thing are fantastic a great tone setter for the record mio mio mio that's where a lot of the album's lyrical themes and narrative become very apparent where we see our protagonists sad over the loss of a connection they had with this person that obviously meant very much to them it's too rare in life to find someone you love that can stick around after thunderclouds it's too rare in life to find someone you love to open up to sometimes and not regret you did - and the vocals on this track are incredibly incredibly distressed in a way that benefits the song also loving the crescendo of noise in the first half of this song the anthemic guitar leads that lead us there the curious instrumental shift after the halfway point and the grand chorus of singers that kind of coast the song out it's very lovely and even bigger feet is the song my Sputnik sweetheart which is a 13 minute epic kicking things off with some very raw and bittersweet guitar chords the vocals are way more buried at the start than I would have liked but once they get louder they really pop in the mix then some kind of tragic but also slightly melodramatic lyrics are revealed but also learn to eat like nothing's left who is your influence losing sense of self in place asking who I love the way the first leg of this track builds up into this swaying heart broken spiral of sadness still on the same track and very nicely into some plucky acoustics and gorgeous vocal harmonies electric guitars then bring the music to another punky rush backed with all these crashing drums then some of the most unhinged vocals on the entire record some of the harshest noise on the entire record and at this point we're only in the middle of the track there's still six minutes or so to go each one of them more thrilling than the last I also love how embarrassing painting serves as a very necessary somewhat mellow and woozy cooled down moment a palate cleanser that really shows that Sputnik is paying very close attention to how all of these tracks flow into each other as long as i mentioning highlights there's also agatha you're being dramatic which features some gorgeous forlorn choral vocals singing some very high notes over crunchy guitars more rough sandpaper drums I really appreciate the change in instrumental palette this song brings it once again reminds me of the flow of the record being so good and how cinematic it all is in a way overall I found coming to be very enjoyable while also flawed in some pretty apparent ways the influences are a bit too obvious there are points where I wish the vocals were a bit more up front or just performed a bit better and yes of course there are parts on this album where the harshness and the low fidelity I think kneecaps the enjoyability still though this is easily one of the more creative rock records I've heard this year one of the more creative lo-fi and indie records I've heard this year I can't claim to be as passionate about it as some of the biggest disciples of this project but this certainly has me looking forward to more I'm feeling a decent too strong 7 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is a another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana weather day come in forever

hi everyone cutie boy can hear the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Brittany Howard record Jamie this is a full-length commercial debut from singer-songwriter guitarist Brittany Howard and Alabama native who's primarily known as being the front woman of the Alabama Shakes this isn't her first musical for a outside of the band though she did have that Thunder bitch record drop in 2015 which was mostly met with very lukewarm reviews but from what I gather this is her first record under her own name a short and sweet project mixing together elements of psyche music blues soul hip hop and loaf I also managing to sound a lot more unorthodox and raw than she's ever sounded in Alabama Shakes brittany undergoes quite the reinvention on this project sounding like a totally different artist on some tracks whether it be on the very intimate and classic sounding vocal jazz ballad short and sweet or the fat beats and very grim spoken word about her racist surroundings growing up on the cut Goathead the production here sounds like something out of a ganja Sufi song also the opening track on this thing history repeats it's groovy its Basie its drum heavy it's a pretty seamless fusion of funk and R&B it's topped with these zany ass vocals that sound like something out of the last D'Angelo record and the production the compression is so blown out that it creates this this very just massive juggernaut sized vibe it's thick it's thicker than a bowl of oatmeal mind you this incredible amount of compression isn't on every track here and on the tracks where it is present it doesn't compliment every one of them so while Jamie is not that long of a record just 35 minutes or so Britney is sounding incredibly bold on this project really letting loose on a lot of tracks here and going on musical and Sonic excursions that I don't think she could have or would have in other contexts and even though the prospect of that is pretty exciting because Howard is incredibly talented still the downside to all of that is the flow of this record is incredibly scattered shot it is just not really sure of what it wants to be at all as an overall-experience so there's little to no consistency on this thing and there are a good chunk of the tracks here that feel like mere impressions of songs or songs that in my opinion don't really resolve like tomorrow or just and abruptly such as baby and presence I have a hard time imagining Britney's listeners who are just into her for the blues stuff for the soul stuff really getting down with tracks like the haunting minimal and distorted run to me or the song 13th century metal one of the most compressed tracks on the entire record and a song that sounds like a part psyche part noise jam that's like a cross between a Velvet Underground song and a religious sermon and look personally I love this track but I wish it was reinforced by other sounds and ideas on the project truly and honestly I think this record is at its catchiest and most consistent in the first leg where again we get that amazing track history repeats which is booming angular impeccably funky it's really out there with its blown out sound it's hypnotic strumming it's angular guitar leads it's very chunky drumming and in squishy keyboards yes they're squishy honest to god they're quite squishy we also have the song he loves me which is lovely it's endearing it also puts a bit of a bittersweet twist on your typical love song it's got these fat drums these dirty projector s guitar leads grimy base and those unapologetic lyrics talking about how Brittany's significant other loves her when she's getting drunk smoking blunts when she does what she wants I also love the track Georgia which by comparison with other cuts here is a lot softer on the ears but still those drums those bass II bits still sound like they could be heavier go harder this track sounds like watching a sumo wrestler pull off a ballet routine the massive gargantuan size is there but still all the instrumentation manages to sound curious and shy meanwhile stay high as easily the most classic and accessible track of the bunch if there is anyone seong on this record that would not sound out of place in the midst of an Alabama Shakes tracklist it is this one still though there are elements of this track that do make it stand out like Britney's vocal performance where she just absolutely kills it to the point where I'm just vocally hearing her in a very different light I mean some of the falsetto she hits on this track almost have a husky kind of manly tone to them and as much as I do enjoy the more left-field and fringe spots throughout this record mostly toward the end there is something in me that wishes there were more cuts like this in the tracklist because at least a good chunk of these experiments either don't finish off all that strongly or don't really feel like they are building toward anything on a record that that very much feels like a potpourri of solid songs but also weird exorcisms of ideas that I feel like Britney just had to get out there on some record it just happened to be this one still got to say I enjoyed this record quite a bit these songs that were well groomed and the experiments that did manage to be the boldest of the bunch certainly had me looking forward to more music from Britney in the future in a solo capacity or at least hoping that in her other projects like Alabama Shakes she manages to work in more left-field ideas such as the ones that landed on this record either way feeling a light too decent 7 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you could check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Brittany Howard forever

ah hi everyone in the nation here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new blink-182 album 9 yes this is the latest full-length LP from big-league California pop punk band blink-182 it's their ninth album hence the title it has now been three years since the group dropped their terrible 2016 album California for years since the band saw a major lineup change with co-songwriter Tom DeLonge leaving the group being replaced by the alkaline trios Matt Skiba and it's now been eight years since the band made the comeback that maybe they shouldn't have with neighborhoods in 2011 and now we have 9 which is is not good it's not a good record it's not very good at all I mean you know it I know it I don't need to lie to you about this it was pretty much common knowledge going into this record that it was not going to live up to blinks best I feel like all I can do at this point is just sit back and watch the variety of ways that blink and just shit on their legacy right now that that's essentially how listening to 9 feels granted there are a few decently written Tunes and choruses on here that are sweet mildly catchy also it's admirable that Marc and Travis do better by Matt on this record by giving him more mic time giving him more songwriting spotlight at least allowing him the space to try to fill Tom's shoes as a songwriter but beyond that I don't really have anything positive to say about this album the production is god-awful it is way too glossy it is way too clean sometimes it's so compressed it's it's crushing its head crushing its depressive just blown out to the point where it's irredeemable and the vocals are so touched up they had the strange chorus tour overdubbed quality about them that just makes them sound alien or inhuman especially on many of Marc's verses I mean listen to the opening vocals on the track happy days this does not sound like Mark Hoppus as much as it sounds like a badly programmed Mark Hoppus AI just singing a lesser version of a song that he would stereotypically sing as some of the twang of guitars and the marching snares on there sounds like a classic blink song but much much less gratifying I'd also like to believe my AI theory also carries over into the songwriting aspects of the record because I can't imagine a person writing down I want to feel happy days happy days happy days happy days walls of isolation inside my pain and just say yep that's it the lyrics get weird as mark describes himself on the opening of the song heaven committing arson I guess then there's the song dark side which is sung by Skiba and sounds like it's about not being able to get a goth girlfriend she doesn't know you exist she doesn't seem to have any interest in you but you follow her to the dark side anyway in an unconsenting fashion I might add I don't know Matt maybe you should have saved this one for the next Alkaline Trio record because I don't know if creeping on goth girls is really like in the blink narrative not that this album isn't loaded with cringy breakup songs that make you worry about everyone involved being in an incredibly unhealthy state of Arrested Development the song I really wish I hated you certainly puts Rivers Cuomo suppose at Peter Pan syndrome in perspective it's a track that makes just about every 90s songwriter who refuses to just branch out into a more mature songwriting style look like a fucking adult mark and company also blame it on their youth on the track blame it on my youth which is loaded with all of these skittering drum edits and bright shouty choruses for the younger Millennials and Zoomers out there I guess plus a boomy drumbeat and keyboard line that sounds like the kickoff to a Matt and Kim song the song runaway features both mark and Matt doing some very dramatic raps singing over a tight drum loop and some very sad keyboard passages it's like what Linkin Park must sound like two people who hate Linkin Park and the transition into this pop punk chorus is so freaking loud and blown out it may cause irreparable damage to your eardrums the song Black Rain is another weird stylistic transition it features all of these pretty aggressive drum beats very fast soaring vocals staccato riffs that read like something out of a gym song maybe even it's a little Baroness inspired I suppose it's interesting to hear them try what they're doing here but I don't think it came out particularly good the song Mitzi's mark putting on that really whiny emo affectation on his voice and writing lyrically from a very dramatic place it's not the worst song here but it is just generic emo pablum at least blink isn't trying to hide it I mean after all they do have a song a few tracks later just titled on some emo shit which is boring yes but come on you're gonna make me wait to listen to this terribly titled song all the way at the end of your record and when I finally get to it you're not even going to give me the satisfaction of hearing you sing on some emo shit in the chorus it certainly would have been a better excuse for a hook than what you have on this track currently it's better than hungover you though which I guess is an attempt at some clever wordplay as I'm hungover because I'm drunk but I'm also hungover you emotionally so there's all these references to essentially being stuck on this relationship stuck on this person but also just waking up just hungover it's also got a weird ass beat that sounds like the band is trying to work some foreign flavor into the mix but it's gentrified to the point where I can't tell what it is are you trying to do a dancehall thing a Latin thing one time two times and what is this awful vocal melody I was all wasted I couldn't see you didn't seem like a choice now you could never leave you who is going to come away from the song humming that it's just darting in every direction and utterly failing at creating a likeable melody the closing track ingeniously is titled remember to forget me if I'm lucky if I'm lucky this is terrible there are only a few passages on a few songs that I thought were okay no wonder pop punk is in dire straits these days and I don't mean to shit on the new generation but when people who have been big influencers in the genre are doing this I'm sure it's tough to see a way forward the terrible vocal processing the sucky songwriting all the sequence drums the blaring over compressed choruses the lyrics the lyrics the lyrics I just cannot stand a great deal of what this album brings forward frankly I'm feeling light too on this transition have you given this album did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I earn you next hit the like if you like please subscribe please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana blink-182 forever

oh yeah hi everyone Yatta Yatta the internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Vivian girls album memory rock trio Vivian girls they're back five years after they're announced break up in 2014 new album once a humble band from New York the Viv's became an overnight sensation on the indie blogosphere after dropping their self-titled record in 2008 also gaining some pretty high praise from established outfits such as pitchfork and AV Club though I think the trio sound was more ahead of the curve than some people may have realized back in 2008 helping to set the table for some pretty major trends in the indie scene for the next five to six years meaning they were there doing their thing before loaf I became a sensation with waves breaking onto the scene meaning they were there before surf rock guitars suddenly became a huge trend thanks to groups such as Beach fossils and the drums and if Vivian girls never existed I fail to see how you get all this very popular dreamy rough indie rock music with a really strong feminine voice whether it be best coast or dum-dum girls or Frankie rose who played with Vivian girls and you could even fast forward to hear the band's influence on newer groups whether it be conscious or not such as Heinz now this is not to say that the Vivian girls happen in a vacuum that they didn't have their contemporaries that they didn't have their influences they most certainly did artists like Jay retard and Black Lips were already killing it at about the time that they burst onto the scene and the roots of low fight indie music go all the way back to the 1980s but Vivian girls base of inspiration spread out much further than that into surf rock and toot we into noise pop into sixties girl groups and classic punk as I remember it they were one of the few bands around this time trying to genuinely make the sounds of the Ramones the Ronettes the ventures and the Jesus and Mary Chain all coexist on the same recording now sadly following this album up the trio hit a bit of a sophomore slump with very so-so record the music scene was flooded with similar sounding bands many of which had a larger commercial appeal and by the time they dropped their third full-length album the band to clean their sound up so much I think they started to lose their original appeal even if it did feature standout singles like heard you say which is easily one of the best tunes the Vivian girls have ever put out the band took a few years past this point to call it quits but now they're back and it's a very odd time for a return I mean the way that the trio helped initiate is pretty much gone now and if it doesn't have a trap beat behind it the mainstream is pretty much deaf to it as well as a good portion of the underground the girls don't sound like they're vying for wide appeal on this one though it's more like they are going back to their very noisy and chaotic roots it's 2008 all over again with the trio bringing that smudgy blaring distorted sound they were once known for but somehow on certain tracks here it is heavier more distorted maybe a bit thicker especially on tracks like most of all and sludge easily the most brooding song the trio has ever put out the guitars on this one are very fuzzy certainly live up to the title of sludge most of this album though does sound like you're hearing the classic make up of Vivian girls record all those noisy ringing almost droning guitars just roaring and roaring it sounds like what you would get if you tried to make a Sun record but with more of a surf rock guitar tone and that sound that wall of sound is basically a canvas for the trio to Laysan all of these wintery chilly strange vocal harmonies that are very breathy very soft the drums especially the snare just pierced through all that noise and in the bass in the background very quietly provides a groove occasionally the trio reels it in a little bit like on the track you're kind of life where these demented warp guitars scream away in the background underneath some very clunky bass then there's these strange metallic chime e tones that dance on top of all of this the sound is pretty twisted the song itself is sour as hell but it offers more clarity sonically than most of the tracks here also comparing this record to the group's earlier work while it is noisy the instrumentation the performances the way everything syncs up it seems a lot more methodically assembled the singing isn't especially good in a traditional sense though and can definitely hold a track back if they are spotlit and not really selling the song all that well namely on the track lonely girl but for the most part there are quite a few strong highlights in the first leg of this thing that seemed to build on the usual Vivian girls blueprint like on the opening track most of all as well as the song something to do which has some of the best momentum and chord changes on the entire thing but for every track like this that stands out there's another that seems to house pretty much the same sound the same aesthetic but the tune at the core of it is just not really all that good like add it again or even the title track on this thing which might even be the most half-baked moment on this entire record and the song all your promises is where and I can't believe I'm saying this because this is not usually a focal point of Vivian girls music but the drums are particularly lackluster here the drumming is not usually like the best thing about a Vivian girls track but it is so tedious and sparse on this one it's really just kind of the snare providing most of the backbone when the percussion could have been doing so much more as this track has one of the most gargantuan walls of guitar and waves of any song here and it just really could have used a bit more support a couple of risks sludge that I mentioned earlier super heavy super noisy also the song I'm far away whose dark groovy bass lines and drums and screaming washes of guitar sounds like the soundtrack to a goth doubt beach party I have my criticisms of this record sure but I didn't find any one track to be outright terrible I just thought there were some tracks quite a few that were underwhelming quite a bit of this record I think sounds very say me to those who might not be all that into Vivian girls incredibly noisy and increasingly abrasive sound on this one I think this is a definitely one of the gutsier records in terms of harshness they've put out so far and even though I do like that quality in Vivian girls music I do have to admit it does suffocate quite a few of the songs here but I mostly feel like this album is a pretty decent comeback for the band hopefully they continue to change things up and right sharper songs and bring the noise I'm feeling a strong six to a light seven on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is a another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Vivian girls forever

hi everyone lick that he fast tanto here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of this new collaborative album featuring igloo Ghost Kai Whiston and baby XYZ so this is a new collaborative record from an interesting trio of characters igloo ghosts who in my opinion is one of the most enigmatic producers of this generation pushing wonky and pushing UK bass and pushing bubblegum bass and pushing a host of other things too jittery new heights with a very mystical and otherworldly flair check out his album neo wax bloom if you haven't already also had two very solid EPS drop last year that I liked quite a bit there is also banger wizard Kai Whiston who also had a pretty nice record drop last year he is on igloo ghosts glue label and then there's baby vocalist songwriter producer whose solo work admittedly I wasn't all that deep into before this mini album of 9 tracks in 28 minutes so yes while there were a few exciting teasers going into this project I was already excited to listen to it given the names involved also to hear how each one of them might maybe break new ground or just do something new and refreshing as a result of just working with another person on a full-length record but aesthetically the sound of this project it's not too far off from what you may have already heard on igloo ghosts two recent EPS both of which make for very beautiful expansive busy almost disorienting electronic music that just sounds like it's from the future from another planet from another dimension in fact there's a whole narrative even lore behind igloo ghost music that deals in pretty much those things whether or not this album adds to that ongoing story though I'm not entirely sure I'm assuming maybe no but again aesthetically I think a lot of the tracks on this record resemble that of the dizzying and mind-expanding compositions that landed on ghosts last couple of EPS but with some subtle changes and additions the bass and the beats certainly go a bit harder I think having a dedicated vocalist collaborating throughout the entire project certainly brings a refreshing dynamic so this thing mostly seems like a very subtle fusion of each artists strengths going into this record and maybe I could see some disappointment coming out of this album from some listeners if you miss how each artists typically sounds and you don't like the compromises each of them make in order to create these tracks or maybe you're not thinking that this project is substantive enough as it is pretty short and I will admit there are some tracks on here where it seems like each artists efforts they cancel each other out a bit and the results just lead to a very so-so song whether it be on drown you where the vocals get really really really tedious I don't care that much for the thin tone I think they get really repetitive I mostly feel the same way about the tracks see-through as well and the track Lux to read to me as if you took a song from ghosts clear teme EP and then through a bunch of tonight style banger beats in the background and vocal chops we do get some truly unique and memorable moments later into the tracklist though we have the Songhua key which was a great teaser track to this thing it sounds like a buzzing raging explosive Whiston style banger but with some of the edges smooth and rounded out with eagle ghosts beautiful mystical synth passages past this point we have some subtle vocal embellishments from baby we have some buzzing fluttering bass notes I like the song mouth shit but it is a little disorienting at first and and I think it's still a bit disorienting now even though I'm kind of used to it because there is a particular sound in the track that sounds like crying toddler is being sampled and if you've ever heard like a kid crying before it may just like get you to look around is there is there a child and look if that is not the source of this sound whatever it is it sounds like something crying and it's it's a again very distracting and takes me out of the track even though I think a lot of the progressions and grooves on this one are pretty cool I found babies singing on teeth tizzle to be surprisingly beautiful easily her best performance on the entire record I loved her weird lyrics and I love the gentler musical passages that her voice was housed in and how that contrasted really nicely with these more aggressive beats and other sections I just wish it were longer I thought the flat beat and very zany somewhat obnoxious samples flying in every direction on barely twins all of that was a bit excessive even though I do generally think the song is pretty fun and the track lamb was an incredibly strong teaser turned incredibly strong closer easily the most robust track of the entire record multifaceted awesome flow I also loved the kick off where baby's very cute monotone wrapped vocal set a very interesting tone for the track however we do reach a second half of the song where we start getting into some very jittery passages that don't sound too much unlike what a cool ghost was doing on his neo wax bloom record but if that similarity doesn't bother you then you should get through this with a smile on your face this project doesn't break new ground for anybody involved I wouldn't say but I think everyone here complements each other really well on a vast majority of the tracks here there wasn't really anything on this record that I thought was terrible just a handful of tracks that I just wanted more from still those moments didn't take away from the cuts here that actually were pretty fantastic all of which make me look forward to seeing these three crossover more into the future hopefully on another full-length project that is a bit longer a bit more ambitious maybe even a bit riskier I'm feeling a light seven on this one transition have you given this record listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next it the like if you like please subscribe and please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is a another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana igloo Ghost Kai Whiston baby forever

hi everyone fly the kite Tanana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new ameer van EP emmanuel this is a new EP from rapper and texas native amir van once a member of the boy band phenomenon known as Brockhampton amir was ousted from the group last year after some abuse allegations were levelled at him van released a pretty unsatisfactory apology and Brock Hampton released a pretty nondescript explanation of the situation in his departure Brock Hampton member donik Lennon later on social media revealed that Amir may have had something to do with a friend of his being jumped something that he goes into lyrical detail about on a song from the group's last full-length album ginger the track dearly departed this whole thing is a great big mess that led to a huge fracture within the group I would say almost ended them certainly it ended the creative streak the group had going up until that point and despite a bit of bounce back on their last full length album ginger which i think is their most cohesive full-length record yet Brock Hampton still has a very vocal portion of their fanbase that seems angry about Aamir leaving and maybe with a mirror now being back putting out his own stuff those people will now have a sense of closure they'll have the ability to listen to his music and get that fill that they desire from that and even though the demand for a mere to be back in music has been loud and has been very present and constant ever since his departure from Brock Hampton maybe his comeback was inevitable maybe it was only a matter of time not sure if the plan was ever for him to disappear from music completely given that when he reappears he has a billboard as well as production from Hit Boy and cool and Dre with some pretty spendy and cleared samples this thing is not just some random indie hip hop project from a guy who's been abandoned by and blackballed in the industry because apparently the distributor for Amir's Winston wolf label that this EP is on is the orchard and even though I don't begrudge Amir his right and ability to come out with his own music and tell things from his own point of view this whole situation just feels like the industry trying to make a profit off of both sides of this very dramatic situation now on this very short EP which is like 15 minutes long a mere does kick up some dust about everything that has transpired over the past year but lyrically and narrative Lee I would say even musically he doesn't give us a whole lot to chew over throughout this thing Aamir comes off as very petty very bitter without even a lick of regret on anything that he may have responsibility for and not to say that Aamir should be automatically understood as guilty of anything he's accused of but he doesn't really take the time on this EP to make the case for himself or prove otherwise instead he's dropping bars on this thing about losing friends and finding it hard to say sorry but I guess with whatever he's saying he's doing it in his usual Amir flow I guess you could say Amir does take some responsibility in acknowledging that his hard upbringing makes it difficult for him to fly right and make the best decisions I get that we're all products of our environment but Amir is clearly self-aware enough to put himself in the right direction if he wanted to he doesn't need to accept his bad behavior as fate or you suicide as an answer to the problems he creates as far as drama on this EP goes the song Los Angeles is even juicier making claims that Brock Hampton are greedily profiting off of his name by mentioning the situation that came about in their songs as if acknowledging this thing that shocked the group shocked their fans and still dodge them to this day is some sort of moral injustice I mean the wrapping on this track is impassioned Amir clearly feels this way legitimately and it features one of the best beats on the entire EP but what a pity party why would I want to sit here and be voluntarily gas-lit finally on the song Sunday night there's another handful of bars that are very clearly connected to this situation I do shit that they wish they could people supposed to stick up for their family but we see they don't I got all that gutter and that meaning that they feigning for so again Amir is not being stuck up for or protected he has a special something that nobody else in the group has and that they need this is essentially the narrative that his most hardcore fans that are angry he's out of the group now have been spinning over the past year if I wanted to be told this I would just go to the Brock Hampton subreddit and also does this EP have that gutter that we are feigning for I mean as far as the lyrics go and the music there is some gun talk some drug talk some traumatic experiences brought up that have obviously shaped a mirror to be who he is today but this thing is far from the nastiest EP of hardcore hip-hop I've heard a mirror is still a unique voice though with a style that sticks out even when he's not at his best lyrically I'm sure that'll be enough to draw some fans in but there is an over lack of attention paid to the choruses on this thing many of which are incredibly subpar or just not there and the instrumentals leave a lot to be desired - not that I expected a mere to hop on all these bouncy Brockhampton esque bangers but one beat after another is just bland trap instrumentals the outro tract does absolutely nothing no point to it even being on this thing and pop trunk is maybe the most painfully generic track on the entire record not to mention just again the chorus not that good I think the one true standout on the entire project lyrically instrumentally musically has to be the song Glock 19 I love the eerie chime e synths in the background I love that Ahmir changes his flow up a bit on this one the rumbling bass the haunting little vocal samples laced into the instrumental our operatic intense delivery from Amir on this track killer chorus I think Amir is a talented artist no doubt in a track like this proves that but if he's going to push forward and be successful he's gonna need to get over himself in the situation and just put up more tracks like this and even if Amir does that I still worry because in the best-case scenario I feel like he's going to hit a point where he still is a bit one-dimensional because his style has sound the topics he usually approaches don't tend to be that varied maybe we will see an evolution from him in the future where he is changing things up and he is taking risks and he is getting outside of his comfort zone I welcome that I guess we'll see that change when he makes his next move on maybe a longer more robust project I'm feeling a light too decent for on this one transition have you given this EP a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what Hey hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new Alex G record House of sugar Alex G is a multi-instrumentalist a producer a loaf eye wizard he is an artist that made it pretty big on the band camp platform until transitioning off of it at the midpoint of the decade with eight Domino Records contract and his profile would grow even bigger a year or so later when named as a collaborator with Frank Ocean on numerous tracks from endless and blonde Alex has a legit reputation as a musical brain and a production talent but I'm yet to be really floored by one of his records all the way through or impressed beyond some of the creative production choices he typically makes in his songs because when it comes to the singing and the songwriting end of things in Alex G's music I am left wanting so much more these were mostly my feelings on his last record in 2017 rocket pretty much a breakthrough record for Alex that even though I was underwhelmed by it I was looking forward to the future hoping to enjoy his next release more not only because I thought a few of the teasers from this new record were good but hey Alex G could also come into his own as an artist in the same way that will Toledo did as he transitioned on to Matador Records and quickly became after a so-so album one of the labels MVPs so as much as I went into this new album with high hopes and just fingers crossed it feels like rocket all over again and not to say that Alex G made the same record twice he didn't I just walked away with a lot of the same complaints and issues and remember this is relative at the end of the day because there are people who are living and dying by the Alex G discography and loved rocket and you know I heard it that those who enjoyed that record are going to love this too maybe even love it more I mean sure by comparison the production generally on house of sugar is a lot less low five I'd say the way Alex mixes and arranges instrumentation on some of the tracks here has actually kind of Orthodox whether it be on the song hope or the track southern sky tracks don't sound too far outside of the purview of Indy balladeers of the 90s and 2000's there's a very apparent Elliott Smith influence on a few key tracks here - I have to admit though Alyx comes up with some amazing gorgeous haunting layers of instrumentation surrounding the acoustics on the track Gretl probably the best tune and instrumental assembly on this whole project the listless vocals and the grunge ish guitar chord progressions as well as the melting descending tones it leaves me feeling like I'm just floating down a river of depression in a relaxed state under a starry sky I'm similarly enchanted by some of the droney hypnotic layers on the track walk away a meditative track that is somehow sparkling but also a little low fine smudgy easily one of the most psychedelic transmissions to come out of the Alex G discography but it's a really odd way to kick off the album it's one of the lengthier tracks on the record a record of songs that generally are somewhat short and not that built out and as far as the song goes there's not really a strong song at the core of this thing and that's the thing while I like the sound and a lot of the instrumental palettes of house of sugar a lot probably even more than rocket the singing and the songwriting hasn't gotten that much better there are some pretty robust and well assembled tunes in the first leg of this thing but after that consistency and structure kind of goes out the window Alex starts bringing these tracks that more or less feel like motifs or vague instrumental ideas as opposed to a complete song it's one short transitional moment after another and yet none of them are really transitioning into anything or reinforcing each other either the song taking sounds like a pretty good instrumental bridge to a fuller song but it's it's not much else it's like we're just not allowed to hear the rest of the track I mean the brightly melodies shimmer beautifully and I love the taking taking hypnotic refrains toward the back end of the track - but again I wish it ended or started somewhere else different the song near is downright the most annoying song on the entire record with it's murky and gargling rhythms and bass the very busy repetitive somewhat jittery vocal parts and harmonies and as well as the guitar passages that seem like they don't really care about where they fit into the track it's like they're just kind of making a mess in the midst of an instrumental that already has too much going on project to essentially sounds like Alex trying his hand at some vaporwave since at the very least a far side virtual ripoff and it's not very compelling then we have another stylistic change right after this with the song bad man which is pretty country influenced sounds like what you would get if you fused a country song with some very busy rhythmic angular indie tronic ax it's tough to put my finger on because it's easily one of the most varied strange and seamless genre fusions on the entire project the instrumental breakdown in the middle is pretty cool and even though this thing is one of the shortest songs on the entire record it feels longer than 1 minute and 50 seconds maybe because the tune coming out of the vocals is so catchy and you have these various very well defined parts that make you feel like you're progressing through something that's pretty well put together also loving how morbid and serene the lyrics are toward the end about a bomb dropping and laying in the grass of the tangerine sky the track sugar though is another head scratcher in the tracklist the vocals are fed through this really weird robotic filter to the point where you can't really tell what they're saying they're squeaky a little warbly honest-to-god it sounds like an animal crossing character it sounds like a freaking animal crossing character but at a lower pitch and sung in a way in a repetitious way where it's it's almost like they're performing a chant I really have no idea it's it's one of the more difficult to interpret and digest ideas on the entire record however the instrumentation happening underneath this is actually some of the grandest on the entire project very regal gorgeous thick the string sections on this song are fantastic yes we're essentially listening to this baroque ish r raakhee type of instrumental that's pretty powerful immense it is a stunningly beautiful out-of-this-world oasis kicking off the last third of record and it links to literally nothing else on the album sounds like nothing else on the album alone it's great but it doesn't really do anything for the flow of the record this tracklist much like that on Alex G's other projects is like a crapshoot of semi-finished songs and offshoot ideas the final moments of this thing are spent delivering one very low key so so bland song after another though there are some ideas within each that do stand out like the slow drone II enveloping guitars on in my arms I love the fuzzy syrupy rough aesthetic of this track but again the songwriting the vocals do literally nothing for me the song cow with its twangy lead guitars sees some of those country vibes coming back over a tune that is semi sweet the vocal harmonies and court progressions on the track crime remind me of what you may get if you took of Montreal and had them write some country tunes which I guess they've they've had some tracks in the past that feel little influenced by that here and there though I think Alex's approach is significantly sadder and a bit more despondent also the vocals have way less personality than anything Kevin Barnes has sung over the course of his career the closing track oddly enough is marked as a live cut and is pretty Pleasant pretty sweet features some groovy bass and sassy keys and saxophone seems like something maybe some Jimmy Buffett fans could get down to over although I can really take or leave this record I am very indifferent toward it though I am impressed that despite the lack of a macro vision for this project Alex still does manage to come up with some great ideas on a micro-level passionate fans who loved Alex's music the way that it is the way that it's been on projects like rocket you're probably going to love this and I guess that's exactly why I continue to not be so won over I'll just have to sit this one out I guess you know feeling at decent 5 on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like if you like please subscribe please don't cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video for you to check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Alex G forever

ah hi everyone char the Neely's tan oh you're the Internet's busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new Charli XCX record Charlie this is the latest full-length LP from British pop futurist Charli XCX who's been putting out music for well over a decade at this point but for me personally it's felt like she's only come into her own artistically over the past several years forging a path for herself in the pop field that a lot of her contemporaries are now only catching up to it's crazy for me to think now that I really used to dislike a lot of Charlie's older music and I guess I still do she's made this incredible transition from one of the least interesting personas in pop to one of those who are most willing to push the envelope now you could attribute a lot of this to her embrace of the bubble gum bass and post pop absurdity of producers working with the pc music label which is by no means a mark against Charlie's artistic vision or originality because while many artists embrace the PC trend for the minute that it was hot charlie is one of the few voices out there who have consistently grown their brand off of the productions of Ag Cooke and guru and easy fun for year after year after year now this latest step in Charlie's studio album evolution feels like for me personally it's been taking forever it has been five years since the release of her last length LP sucker which in comparison to this sounds completely different worlds apart since then Charlie has been honing her new direction with some smaller releases with some mixtapes the very fantastic vrooom vrooom EP pop to number one angel and i love a lot of tracks off these projects I like the direction of these projects but I still got the feeling they were a little rough around the edges not the complete package Charlie wasn't gonna come out with a record until she had perfected got right exactly what it is she's trying to do and also not without getting some big names to come onboard as well because over the past several years Charlie has embraced collaborations in such a big way racking up features on this record in the same way a mainstream rapper would Troye Sivan the hyams sisters lizzo sky ferreira christina the queens just to name a few so with more production from AG cook as well as complementary performances from voices across the pop spectrum not to mention numerous singles from this record being incredibly good this thing was building up to be one of my most anticipated records of the year the expectations for me personally were reaching a point where I was getting afraid Oh No this records never going to like be as good as I want it to be but actually it is as good as I wanted it to be maybe a little bit better oh it's such a good pop album and don't get it twisted this is a pop album I'm not trying to oversell the experimentation or the futuristic aspects of Charley's music on this record this thing isn't some kind of weird post pop experiment but what I love about this record is that it effectively balances experimentation and trusty pop formulas in a very nice way as far as a few of the weirder spots on here that are a little reminiscent of ideas off of number one angel or wroom wroom we have tracks like clique which is a roaring banger with kim Petrus as well as Estonian rapper Tommy Cash whose previous input on Charlie's material I didn't really care for but I actually liked his feature quite a bit here the glitchy abrasive beat on this thing is incredible the very noisy noisy noisy outros freaky as hell the braggadocious and auto-tune mix of rapping and singing throughout the track is really nice Kim and Tommy adds so much to the absolutely zany flavor of this track it's like this weird synthetic again I'll say futuristic mix of rap and pop and who knows what else there is the song thoughts that originally was a bit of an adjustment for me the slow pace the ringing and whipping synthesizers coming at you in every direction and they're they're very deeply layered all of the vocal processing and auto-tune on Charlie's voices is very bold very in-your-face their few pop artists on Charlie's level that are embracing digital aesthetics in the way that she is on the tract to the point where she sounds like she is an AI singing her swan song as the building that houses her mainframe is burning down it's really off-putting at first the track sounds alien but also soulful the lyrics meanwhile are full of regret and just basically about missing someone and the final odd moment on this record is the track shake it and this track is amazing if not merely for the fact that Charlie is the only artist out there right now who would have and who could get Big Freedia the queen of Bounce cupcake wrapper cupcake also Pablo guitar a Brazilian pop singer and drag queen as well as brick candy all on the same track and yet it all makes sense I also love that there are some melodic bits as well as some through line grooves that carry the entire track while every different passage for every different person on this song shifts or changes in some significant way to complement their style essentially making the song the one train of pop bangers I love the Sinister fluttery melting whaling string ish synths that occur under big Freitas appearance here there's also cupcake who suddenly drops into these yin yang twins s whisper raps Brooke candies features absolutely raunchy and demented meanwhile Pablo sings over an overblown distorted flip of the original beat so while these tracks do account for the weirdest moments on the record I wouldn't say they stick out like a sore thumb or anything like that they fit very nicely within the overall aesthetics of the album they just add a bit more spice and flavor and variety to the tracklist the rest of the record though is pretty clean consistent and laser focused on producing pop anthems pop ragers pop ballads even though there are a lot of sounds on this thing that feel as if they're coming from a distant future let me remind you that nothing on this record would not be possible without huge huge huge huge huge amounts of influence coming from the eras of 80s synth-pop or 2000s dance pop especially on key tracks like 1999 featuring Troye Sivan which is a total throwback sonically and thematically as the track is essentially about Charlie thinking back to a time where things were simpler things were nicer things were easier also kind of for back to references to music based pop culture at that time the whole thing sounds like a pristine and updated tribute to an era of boy bands pop divas y2k and TRL now in 1999 Charli XCX would have been 7 I don't know how much of the nostalgia she's basing this track on is is personal nostalgia or if she is just referencing a memory of an idea either way as someone who is maybe a bit more conscious during that era because I am older than her I think she's recaptured the the musical and aesthetic vibe of this era very very well we have more pop lists on the track blame it on your love now featuring Liz oh this song was originally track 10 off of pop 2 and in that version of the song it was this weird droney ballad that felt like it was existing in some kind of glitched out matrix but now it is this arena sized very urgent and melodramatic pop anthem with intimate verses a fantastic feature from Liz O on the back end this version is definitely a lot more orthodox than the track 10 version but I love both for different reasons you have to admit even if you like that weirder version the dynamic and decadent take on this this new edition of the track is something to behold the flow of this entire project - I have to remark is pretty impeccable there are lots of great high-energy cuts in the first half you have the very powerful gone featuring Christine and the queens which was one of the best pop songs of the year the day it came out it hits so hard and yet it is so glossy it's so sleek the chemistry between Charlie and Chris is great some of the tight rhythms and Chris's very strained little vocal embellishments are very very reminiscent of Michael Jackson I just love how huge the production of this track feels how huge the performance feels it's just larger than life there's also cross you out featuring sky ferreira which at first I did not care for all that much but with repeated listens I appreciate it a lot more and that was mostly because the beat is kind of a slog the pacing of this song I don't think is going to be for everybody but as I hear it more I like the growling industrial ish in the background I love how the production gets thicker and thicker and heavier and heavier as it progresses along the whole thing becomes pretty immense at the point where Charlie and Skye are hitting you with all of those vocal harmonies on the refrain of the track at the very final moments the vocal break the sky brings to the table right before those last spots are a very nice transition and in a great low-key moment to make the shock of the final climax hit so much harder the only track in the first leg that really truly fell flat for me was the song warm with Higham and it's not that there aren't good ideas on this track there are it's just that I wish there was more contrast through the song more separation between the verses and choruses more progression across the track so that it feels like I am moving through this thing instead of just cycling through the same beats after the midpoint of this project we hit a row of moodier mellower tracks that I think provide a nice I guess a vulnerable spot on the record we have the song white Mercedes which is another glistening love song but what about not being good enough the person who you have in mind always forgiving you when you hurt them this person making you better you not deserving this person the track features an impeccable hook backed by a very familiar chord progression but it does not take away from how powerfully sad this chorus is I also cannot get enough of the thumping buzzing almost lo-fi aesthetic of the song silver cross it has all these passages and melodies that are just darting in every direction they're so angular but still the song at the core of it is incredibly sweet and gratifying just like a righteous ass pop song should be the song I don't want to know is a pretty vulnerable moment on the record a very raw spotlit synth back ballad it's kind of a dirge there's a lot of emotional potency there but I still wish there was more meat on the bone instrumentally the mix generally is pretty washed out to the point where everything sounds really mushy I much prefer the very intimate and subtle official which is not only about I guess confirming love confirming the idea or the existence of a relationship but the swirling little electronic embellishments around this tuner so pretty it's like being transported into a digital fantasy garden I went into this thing already pretty impressed with February 2017 within the context of the tracklist it feels more like a transitional moment bringing us to the album's grand finale with 2099 the album is also booked ended by two fantastic songs as the intro feels like we are essentially booting up to a new version an upgrade of pop music itself meanwhile 2099 which sees Troye Sivan coming back is like a semi dystopian send-off which looks forward to a potentially darker future for pop music and maybe even society itself I think it's pretty fitting that the closing lines on this hook I pull up roll up fuck up don't make decisions for me you don't know nothing and also I'm Pluto Neptune pull up roll up future future their spots and the lyrics on this thing to feel disorienting spots that feel like they're fearing control or some kind of authoritarianism in a way and then again there's also that look to that future some bits of the instrumental or kind of harsh very glitchy and odd it's a satisfying finish that also leaves us on somewhat of a dark cliffhanger in a way it is not only a defining moment for Charlie but I also think a defining moment for pop this decade which potentially sets us on a path for the shape of pop to come and look I'm not gonna argue that this is the most cutting edge things happening in music across the board right now that's not my argument what I'm saying is I'm impressed with how well performed well produced sweet catchy and enjoyable this project is while simultaneously in a very creative way working in some of those futuristic and forward-thinking elements to add a bit of edge add a bit of flair to me that is what Charlie does well here so impeccably well in fact I would say she killed it there were a few tracks that yes I think could have been better with some very small changes but for the most part I was very impressed with this from front to back feeling that a decent a strong nine on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you're the best you're the best what should I review next hit the like feel like please subscribe please don't cry hit the Bell as well or you're next to my head is another video for you to check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony Fantana Charlie XCX Charlie the forever

Oh hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new jpeg mafia album all my heroes are corn balls this is a new album from producer rapper singer-songwriter mr. jpeg mafia who suddenly became an overnight sensation in the hip hop underground shortly after the release of his album last year veteran I've been aware of PEGI stuff for a while I took the time in 2016 to celebrate his incredibly confrontational single with freaky I might vote for Donald Trump which was one of my favorite songs of the year and also early works of his like black Ben Carson I thought certainly had a lot of untapped potential potential that was fulfilled on veteran which is still an incredibly radical fucking record uncompromising challenging aggressive and yet so deeply in tune with much of what makes mainstream hip-hop as appealing as it is constantly borrowing from it whether it be with a bit of an accessible flow or rhythm and then subverting it on a track like 1530 $19 calvert thug tears Macaulay Culkin as well as who can forget I cannot fucking wait until Morrissey dies simply labeling JPEG mafia as abstract or experimental or even industrial hip-hop it doesn't really give you much of a picture of anything that he does especially considering his consistently edgy political and in your face lyrical content as well as how disorienting and unpredictable the flows of his projects tend to be it's like it's all functioning on a gigantic very unhealthy mood swing so going into this new PEGI project I hoped it would be out there I thought it would be especially given the vibe of the teaser tracks more or less I expected the Pegman to stick to his guns and continue delivering those esoteric slaps I didn't necessarily foresee him doing more singing on this record though bringing in a bit more influence from the worlds of pop and R&B especially as he goes on his own melodic interpretation of TLC's no scrubs during one of the interlude cuts here even though he didn't do a whole ton of it on veteran Peggy singing on his own songs is nothing but it's really the emotion the vibe the mood of this record that feels different and unique from every other project Peggy has dropped up until this point and for some reason this has made corn balls at least for me a bit more difficult to sum up than veteran it's not nearly as obvious or as straightforward as veteran was and that record was already pretty Impressionists in nature constantly changing but still greater than the sum of its loosely associated parts the increase in moody synthetics and tuneful singing and vapor wavy textures and sound palettes has led to an experience that is a lot mellower and even more depressive than any JPEG project up until this point which is not necessarily a bad thing because I think Peggy shows a knack for writing these alt rap dirges if you could call them that there were some pretty key and alien synth passages on PTSD on beta male strategies on the end of the dots freestyle as well as grimy waifu that sound like they are straight out of a vapor wave album taking all of these changes in I'm not surprised that Peggy with semi ironically promote this record telling fans they're going to be disappointed with it because I think corn balls does ask a lot more from fans than veteran did I'm not even sure if I'm crazy about everything going on on this LP but I guess I'm happy Peggy didn't make the same record all over again but there were quite a few songs in the tracklist that for me felt very uncommon tum' or theme or central idea across their runtime especially toward the end of the project like the dots freestyle which I think kicks off well enough low key beat smooth flows witty rhymes but just starts trailing off in a really unsatisfactory way after the guest vocal comes in and then again we transition into that weird vapor wavy passage that while I don't mind it in theory it just feels really tacked on the post verified live style has a lot of admirable parts to it but the disjointed structure of it all makes me wonder what exactly this track is trying to be is it an instrumental with what sounds like found sound effects is it a weird vocal snippet or scale it's just like I'm being constantly shifted back and forth between listening to a snippet or rather just one fifth of several different songs thought tactics I thought had some good bars and a great vocal line from Peggy toward the end but the very subdued and glitchy beat just felt like a hodgepodge sort of weak foundation for the song and a giggly outro that just feels like one more distraction from the fact that a song here didn't really have a strong ending and while I am complaining I guess I'll point out the track life's hard here's a song about sorrel which is excruciatingly not only does the instrumental feel like a OneNote Rick's point never replicas rip off but the purposefully horrendous strained auto-tuned singing thrown on top of that is just a very difficult lesson thankfully there are many more positives than negatives throughout the tracklist on this thing especially on the more tuneful cuts here the opening track Jesus forgive me I am a thot you better count your blessings phobia I love the glassy and distant keys on this track and the bass is heavy as hell Peggy delivering all these coarse and dark humored bars many of which seem to center around his creative process it may in fact be a comment on his popularity and him operating within the music industry in the state that
